reviewText:
Early Access Review

I went into this game hesitantly after doing some research on it and I haven't regretted it.  I'm a huge fan of survival/apocalypse type games and, although I'm not too keen on permadeaths and rogue-likes, in this game, it doesn't bother me as much.  NEO Scavenger is challenging and requires a lot of conservative thought if you hope to survive as every decision, every chioce and every action you make, matters.

As of writing this, the game is still in Early Access but it is definitely playable.  My only gripe is that combat is extremely stressful (well, for me it is) and I can't help but feel that the AI cheats.  Even when I do my utmost best to hide and cover my tracks to try and avoid combat it's almost as if the enemies are psychic and always find me regardless.

In my opinion it feels more like a simulation than a game, in that, sometimes I'm not having fun.  Situations will arise where I second and third-guess every move I make and wonder if the next turn will be my last.  Sometimes I'm under so much duress I need to take a break to let my adrenaline subside.  Not that this is a bad thing, mind you.  I suppose I just get too immersed.

NEO Scavenger is a great game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys the hardcore survival genre.

reviewText:
The main problem with NEO Scavenger is, sadly, the scavenging. While there's a decent bit of good writing to be found,  you'll probably never discover it unless you edit the game files or get incredibly lucky with your scavenging rewards, as health, weariness and thirst tick down with absurd speeds, areas get tapped out of resources in no-time(meaning that setting up a camp, which is necessary unless you get ridiculously lucky finding backpacks, etc. is useless) and all your items decay with ridiculous rapidity, too.

You'll never really get to actually PLAY the game, is the thing, you'll be stuck doing nothing but grinding berries, cured meat and boiled water(which you can only get if you're lucky enough to find a saucepan), and then when you finally get enough of it to start moving somewhere... your backpack falls apart and you have to leave it all behind.

But, okay, let's say you're good at management and overcome that hurdle. Then you may find one of the twenty or so locations you can interact with beyond scavenging(in a map of thousands of hexes, and only a few of them look any different from the surrounding generic town hexes)... and whatever you do roughly has a 50% chance of instakilling you or losing you all your carried stuff.

So now, good luck, you can do all your grinding again! Hope you're lucky enough to find a saucepan early on this time around, too, or you may as well just restart.

The combat also boasts a lot of choices to make, but it boils down to either: Have a ranged weapon, keep distance, shoot shoot shoot, or have melee weapon, close distance, beat beat beat. A few of the other options might occasionally be tempting if the game gave any indication of how likely they were to succeed or not(say, percentages or odds or something) rather than just vaguely suggesting a high" or "low" chance(what's high? 50+%? 75+%? 95+%?).

Long story short: Needs more obvious mechanics
date: needs less busywork to pad out playtime
recommended: needs to make consequences of choices more predictable/obvious OR it needs some sort of save function. It feels like someone played FTL and A Dark Room and wanted to copy them without understanding them."

reviewText:
It feels like I've still just scratched the surface but it has been a pretty unique survival roguelike experience that introduces a mix of new mechanics that work together quite well.

+ character attributes: it's not like a typical roguelike where you have you basic generic stats and grind xp. You pick out traits to help define your character (melee, ranged, mechanic, athletic, strong etc) and can pick weaknesses as well which let you get more points on good traits as a tradeoff and allow you to try to balance unique builds. These attributes influence completely what sort of actions you'll have available to you, how you handle conflicts, crafting, trying to find shelter, heat, food and so on. They define and influence your decisions way beyond the normal str,int,con type character building.

+ crafting : there is quite a complex crafting system in place that is entirely based on resources available and the traits you picked. If you find just the right ingredients in the early game to make a decent weapon or clothes you'll have a much easier time, otherwise you'll want to avoid conflicts and scavange more.

+(mostly) combat : deciding whether to fight, and how to fight is very important here.. not because you fight all the time but because the stakes are high and a few bad streaks could see you left bleeding in a field far from your shelter. I like this change to slightly more realistic combat. There's no visible health bar, it's all about waiting till you get a chance to strike, wounding your opponent, and then kicking while they are down. Not particularly heroic but if you make a mistake that leaves you vulnerable and they get a hit in, they'll do the same to you. It comes down primarily to trying to get in range for your weapon, stay out of range from theirs, and defend yourself until you have an opportunity. For example, if you have a melee weapon you can try to rush them but you risk falling on your butt at which point you'd be an open target, or you can advance normally but they'll be able to back away.

- combat balance: My con with this is that your weapons make all the difference and with the random nature and limited weapon types, you can either be useless in combat or feel like there was no risk. In my first play through I believe I hit a guy with a pocket knife like 20 times until he ran away after punching me and then I bled to death. In my second playthrough I tied a knife to a stick to make a spear, with a range of 3 is the longest melee weapon. And then proceeded to kill everyone that didn't have a gun without a scratch because they couldn't get near me without getting stabbed. And those with guns I could sneak on fairly easy and then once I hit them they were too wounded to fight back. It went from combat being impossible to being 'meh'.

reviewText:
I will try to keep it brief and describe my games in a very brief manner. Each number, represents a different game from the start.

1. I came out of the building, felt disoriented and not sure what to do. Something nasty came to me and attacked. I tried to defend myself but I bled out after the series of injuries.

2. This time I had time to wander some more, I found some mushrooms, berries, sharpened a big stick and waited for trouble... but I froze to death.

3. Shortly after I came out, the feral dog sneaked on me and attacked. I was fighing furiously with my punches, until I damaged his brain with concussions. I would have never thought that reading about the combat could be so exciting: bruises, cuts, bites, concussions, bleedings... all those details were amazing. My brain did the rest, imaging myself fighting for life with this dog. When he dropped dead, I patched up my wounds, took some painkillers and gutted him, took 2 small pieces of raw meat into my small medkit and moved along to find some clothes before I freeze to death again. I went to the city and scavenged it. I found plenty of goody goodies: crowbar with strap, binoculars with strap too!, cardboard box, cargo pants (with pockets!=more slots, yea!), T-shirt and some straps. Now, I am afraid to go out, because I don't want to loose all my treasure :( . T-shirt, cargo pants, hospistal gown on top of it all, holding crowbar in one hand and cardboard box with my treasure in the other one... time to move on. I go to the next building, I must be lucky, plenty of other  goods but I have no space to take it... First dillemma: break bottle and use it to make small campfire or leave it as a container for water later on? To hell with it... I might not live so long and I need warmth. OMFG! I had not enough points and had to end the turn, now the sun is gone... After a while it came out again, now I sit in front of a campfire, eating a cooked dog meat and think what to do next. The fire is not big enough, I move to the forest for more wood, some stranger attacks me, I try to talk to with him, he's confused but still charges at me... Time to cave his head in with the brand new crowbar. WTF!? He is some kind of a boxer! He keeps punching me and avoiding my crowbar! I cough up with blood and have got internal bleeding! After a short fight, I pass out and this guy is checking for loot on me... I wake up, beaten drastically, he retreated. MOTHERF**ER stole my cardboard box with goodies!!! I was on my way back to the camp when I have found an old car and a sleeping bag in it. Resting in the filhty but warm sleeping bag in abandoned IT office building, curing my heavy injuries, a mysterious horror creature woke me up. I had to run away, leaving my sleeping bag behind... After a while of running away, I had to go back, the cold rain has started to rain and it was a night... I know that my end is near but I keep sneaking in the dark trying to get into my warm sleeping bag... I just hope it is not sleeping in it... LMAO I threatened it with my crowbar and it ran away!!! I can't believe it!@ Sleeping, resting and healing in my precious filthy sleeping bag. After many hours, something is creeping on me once again. It's dark and we do not see each other yet, I will run away, I need some water anyways. It was a feral dog, I took some bites and I am bleeding but the dog is dead. I rest some more, take a bottle and go to look for some water, I find a small lake, drink a lot and take some with me, in a small plastic bottle.

reviewText:
NEO Scavenger is a game that you should defiently pick up if you enjoy DayZ and those sorts of games, or if you want to see what kind of person are you

NEO Scavenger's weak points:
-Alot of the times, when you have maximum chance of getting loot, you won't get any (tl:dr loot is heavily randomized)
-Prepare to die

Neo Scavenger's strong points:
-Unforgiving
-It get's rewarding really fast
-The combat is brutal

Neo Scavenger made me rethink how I see life and showed me how desensitized I am to killing living, breathing humans and animals. It's a game that will beat you up, eat you and then spit you out. It's worth every cent, dollar, euro, whatever.

reviewText:
One of the best indie game that i ever played, this game really delivers.
It's a turn-based post-apocalyptic RPG, with perma-death rouguelike action.

You spend your time trying to survive, therefore finding something to eat, to drink, decent clothes to avoid hypotermia, weapons to fight with bandits, looters, cannibals, feral dogs and other demoniac creatures, medicines/bandages to avoid illness,etc. And then, if you are still alive and have spare time and enough courage to risk your life, you will also try to discover the truth behind yur past, exploring the wilderness.

The game is reckless, brutal but so beautiful, a truly hidden gem.
Buy it.

reviewText:
- Highly original turn-based survival game.
- Think very carefully about your next move as biting off more than you can chew will end up with you being bitten off and chewed.
- Very satisfying to scavenge and carefully arrange all of your loot, choose a good base, and take on the post-apocalyptic world.
- Replayable due to different character builds, random map generation, and choice of approach
- In-depth, detailed crafting and injury system that is reminiscent of Dwarf Fortress' detail.
- Unique combat with a heavy focus on strategy and avoiding injury rather than mindlessly hack and slashing.
- Great writing and intriguing premise.
- Interface looks intimidating but is suprisingly easy to learn.
- Pick up and play for ten minutes, or get lost for hours.
- Permadeath makes it all real.

reviewText:
So I really, really wanted to like this game, because the amount of potential in this game is absolutely tremendous. The interplay between different systems and the really neat environment and design decisions should have made a great game.

It didn't. There's not enough content for this game to shine, and because there's so little content the problems it has are made starkly apparent. Permadeath is not an inherently good or bad decision, but what it does in a game like NEO Scavenger is force the player through the same few bits of content over and over again. That content has an optimized solution, which means the first 5-10 minutes of every play-through are doing the exact same thing, every time, with no reason or reward from deviating from it. And then you end up at one of the pieces of game content that you _did_ play before, with functionally identical choices. And then you die, fairly or unfairly (and this game _loves_ unfair deaths), and you get to do it again.

A simulation game has to hide its brain to be deeply rewarding. This doesn't, and the narrative and the neat bits do not carry it through. Buy it for a couple bucks and play it once or twice, but at list price it is emphatically not worth your money because it will not respect your time.

reviewText:
NEO Scavenger is a rather simple, yet in-depth post-apocalyptic strategy RPG game(woah lots of adjectives). You start off in a Cryo Facility and find yourself roaming a world ravaged by an unknown apocalpyse. The game is turn-based so you have enough time to carefully plan your next move, or end up perishing. The game offers lots of choices as to how you're going to proceed. Fight or Flight? Eat or not? Explore or abandon? The RPG elements are great and there is a lot of detail in the overall health system(pain, blood, temperature...), lots of possible customization, all of it affecting your player(having a rough air filter just might save you from an allergic reaction, or the inhalation of toxic spores). The game takes time to master and lots of luck as well, even after 10 hours I still find new things around the game(randomly generated map, but still unable to scavenge all of it), and still find the dumbest ways to die.

10/10, slipped and fell, died whilst unconscious. (jk) PROTIP: Start with Medic and Botanist Perks.

>I'd give it a 10/10
>Pros: Leaves you to imagine most of it, great customization, detailed health and inventory system, replayability, hard and challenging, lots of points of interest, many more great things!
>Cons: Sometimes you won't be able to really understand something until it kills you.

reviewText:
Man I totally understand the love I see for this game but I just can't get behind it. I enjoyed this game and have alot of respect for roguelike game that manages to tell an intersting and detailed story. Ultimately the reason I have to give this the thumbs down is because of the terrible user interface and menu system that just flat out needs to be better.

The game is a challenging one unfortunetly most of the challenge I faced was figuring out to navigate the complete mess of a menu system. Now once you get the menu system down the experience is much improved. I was reminded of how awful the menu system was after I had to put the game down for a few weeks and came back to find I had forgotten some of the ins and outs of the game and I just can't bring myself to try it again.

I can handle bad graphics and some game play flaws but there are just too many here for me to ignore. There's some stuff to like here but overall its just not worth the price tag.

4/10

reviewText: I don't know, maybe this game gets as good as I keep seeing people say it is after you survive a little while and get some gear, but that's the thing: I can't. Every game I played started and ended the same way: I wandered around, scavenged for items, found nothing or barely anything (one game I found some pants; another, a multitool; every other game I would find a single shoe), then got attacked and killed. No matter if I tried to run or hide, I would eventually get attacked by an enemy and die. I couldn't fight, because I found no weapons. I was constantly getting sick, because I found no clothes. I'm all for games being tough, but when literally all I'm finding everywhere I go is dirty rags and plastic shopping bags, it's not fun. Maybe I'm doing something wrong and should look up strategies on how to survive, but I think games should have a minimum amount of playability without having to use outside resources, and this one doesn't, so I can't recommend it. I'm sad about that, because I followed it through Early Access and waited to play until release, really looking forward to it, but there's not holding your hand and there's not giving you any direction at all, and this game falls into the latter category for me. Your experience may vary.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A brutally hard survival game. If you are feeling a masochist, pick this.

Jokes aside, although the only control you have on you caracter is on the inventory management and choosing which actions to perform, I can assure you that this is one of the most complex survival games available in Steam. Due to it's level of difficulty, I suggest you play this on short bursts (as on the first playthroughts you won't last that long anyway :P )

PROS:
-Excellent atmosphere that absorves you into it's post-apocaliptyc setting.
-The sound is great, from the realistic effects to the music.
-Every choice has a consequence, even a choice as deceptevly simple as drinking a bottle of water that you just found
-I would dare to say that the depth of the game's survival mechanics are unparalelled.
-There is an actual main storyline to this game shall you choose to follow it.

CONS:
-It is a very difficult game. I have 6+ hours on this game by the time I am writing this, and I still take a beating every time. I tottaly understand if many people are put off by it.

-The learning curve: I will be honest. This game has TONS of trial and error. Only after the first 5 playthroughs(about 2 hours of playing), you will be able to understand why you have died. From there, the game gets more satisfying, but adding to the complex interface and the fact that the game almost begs you to seek vital information (such as important crafting recipes) to the game's wiki page.

Having said that, if you are looking for a challenge, you certainly have one here. If I were to call this game by other name, it would be Bear Grylls Simulator.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you like Fallout and you like survival games, Neo Scavenger is the game for you. It's one of the best RPGs I've played in a long time, with tons of exploration, meaningful choices with actual consequences, and tons of different ways to approach any problem. Most challenges are easily overcome if you're prepared, but the same challenges can still easily kill you if you rush in, and in most cases you only get one chance. Enemy threats are easily distinguishable on the world map, with all NPCs shown wearing the equipment they're carrying, which lets you guess at their faction, disposition, and danger level. Also, you get to kick a dogman's ♥♥♥ with your bare hands.

Pros:
- Exploration
- Meaningful consequences to choices
- Lots of interactions and events
- Great art
- Traits used often and in useful ways

Cons:
- Somewhat limited variety crafting system
- Crafting slows down noticeably when carrying lots of items, and may break sometimes
- You -will- spend a lot of time playing inventory tetris
- Be warned, this is a permadeath game (for those who this is a con)

reviewText:
This game is really, really good.  It's got an interesting story, but you can ignore it and carve out your own tale if you so choose.

However, I feel there are two problems with this game:

Firstly, the world seems pretty much dead.  Except for one story location, there doesn't seem to be anyone anywhere except hostile bandits and looters who are willing to not murder you on sight if you agree to not murder them on sight.  In my opinion, the world should feel just a little bit more alive.

Secondly, the game is TOO brutal.  I get that it's a roguelike and roguelikes are supposed to be tough, but there's a lot of things that, quite frankly, are full of ♥♥♥♥.

I once stabbed a guy with a long, pointed tree branch made into a spear.  According to the game text, I viciously stabbed his upper stomach, and according to the in-game status text, he was bleeding heavily, in shock, and on the ground.  Somehow he managed to knock me out in one punch, steal my spear and backpack, and run away before I woke up, got an infection and died.

Several times I've started a brand new game just to not find any early game drops and freeze to death within a minute.  No hyperbole, I died within a single minute of starting a new game thanks to the RNG.  Other times I'll be walking around the game world and suddenly I've got diiarhea and I'm vomiting and my stomach hurts and I'm dead.


Don't get me wrong, this game is loads of fun to play and you should definitely give it a try if you like roguelikes and randomly-generated game worlds, but there's a lot of things that make me scream and swear at the game when I really shouldn't be.

Overall, I would indeed recommend this game.  7.8/10

Permadeath seems harsh the first few times, but after playing for a while you understand it is a requirement for this type of game (otherwise you would save/load at each small obstacle or mistake). Getting looted while sleeping in an unprepared campsite, dying of infection due to fatigue and untended wounds, starving or freezing to death... All these options" make for a great game with completely different approaches. The palette of skills proposed during the setup phase allows for different gameplays."

reviewText:
TLDR:  A good turn based survival game with neat setting and mechanics.

NEO Scavenger is a turn-based survival game whose difficulty I'd call 'tough but fair' once you get the  hang of the mechanics.  You play as Philip Kindred, a man who has lost most of his memories after being rudely awakened from his cryogenic-sleep pod in the near future.  The game is set in post-apocalyptic Michigan, with a mix of supernatural/horror and sci-fi elements.  Overall it reminds me of Fallout 1 and 2 in terms of tone and atmosphere.

Something you should definitely be aware of before buying: Permadeath!  There is only one save slot in NEO Scavenger and when you die the game deletes the savegame, forcing you to start over.  However you can get around this fairly simply by manually backing up your savegame files after you save, so even players who don't like permadeath should still be able to enjoy NEO Scavenger if they save often and remember to back up those save files.  (I believe there is also a mod that adds multiple save slots, or that automatically backs up your save game, or something like that.  I never tried it out myself, so I can't comment on it.)

NEO Scavenger is a text heavy game, and there is no narrator or voice acting.  Talking with friendly NPCs and fighting hostile ones both involve plenty of text.  Not that the game doesn't have a good UI too, but the lore and details of the game are all conveyed through text.

Speaking of which, the story of the game is told rather subtly, which I like but some people might not.  You'll have to search for clues to who you are and what's going on in the world.  Talking to NPCs, investigating strange locations, even simply finding and reading ancient newspaper article could tell you something important about the world of NEO Scavenger.  My point is you are going to have to really explore the game to uncover the plot.

There is an end to the story after which you cannot keep playing, but the game is pretty clear that going to that area is a fairly big deal and you are never forced to do so.

One of my favorite ways NEO Scavenger tells you about the world (and lets you tell the game what sort of person 'your' Philip Kindred is) is through random events.  These events will pop up occasionally as you explore the map, present you with a situation/problem, and a number of choices to deal with said situation/problem.  They're a bit like a single-page Choose-Your-Own-Adventure games.  Though sometimes a bad choice can get you eaten, so keep what I said about backing up your saves in mind if you dislike permadeath.  I've found several dozen of them so far and the choices and their outcomes are generally very satisfying.  There was one that actually let me ask for more information before deciding whether to help a slightly suspicious person, which is something I've often lamented a lack of in other games.

There's also a small modding scene, despite the lack of Steam Workshop support (flash and steam don't work well together apparently).  Check out the forums of the Blue Bottle Games website or Nexus mods for those.

Finally, I just want to mention that the actual total hours I've played this game are at least twice of what Steam says it is.  This is because I bought the game through the developers website and generally play the version I downloaded there.  Speaking of which. if you do decide you want to buy the full game, you can get NEO Scavenger DRM free on Good Old Games, or directly through the Blue Bottle Games website.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
NEO Scavenger was on my wishlist for a long time, $15 seemed steep for a graphics/text game, let alone a rogue-like. Well, I got drunk one night and impulsively hit 'buy'. So now I have it, and I like it enough to give a review, which I don't usually do.

NEO is brutal. This isn't the type of game where you play the ultra-altruistic Hero" that saves everybody and looks good doing it. You'll live a lot longer if you take the attitude of "desperate homeless guy that doesn't want to get involved in your ♥♥♥♥".

When you die
date: it's over. No going back to a previous save. You just start over from scratch.\n\nThe learning curve is a little bit steep
recommended: but so rewarding once you get there. My first several hours I went through at least half a dozen deaths. I learned to avoid fights. To clean my wounds before bandaging them. I learned to not ever eat yellow berries. I rage quit twice. I came back twice.\n\nNow
hoursPlayed: I've got a rifle (with ELEVEN bullets!)
voteText: a warm coat and enough clean water to last me a week. I'm unstoppable
helpfulPercent: king of all there is in this wasteland.\n\nExcept that I'm not. I still run away from everything that moves
votesHelpful: I only camp in secluded buildings
votesTotal:
diligently cover my tracks behind me and always keep an eye over my shoulder.

And that's how it should be. I survived for this long because I learned how to live in the wasteland. I didn't get a bunch of XP from slaughtering hundreds of enemies and then suddenly become immune to a bullet to the brainpan.

That's what I love about this game. The "XP" is your own damn brain. Learning how to craft the things you need. How to avoid those looters in the distance. Knowing that I've gotten as far as I have by not making mistakes.

NEO has an outrageous amount of complexity that you would never know exists until you go looking for it. If you're on the fence
votesFunny: just buy it. Well worth the money spent.\n\nOne last tip: If you're new
commentsCount: take botany. Makes the game a little more forgiving since you won't really have to worry about food & drink.\n"

reviewText:
In light of the fact that this game is done being developed, I've decided to rewrite my review.

A fantastic game in which you have to survive in a world that isn't so much out to kill you as it just doesn't care that you exist. You don't get superpowers, crazy damage resistence, favorable loot spawns or anything like that, you are just another person scrounging a living off the wasteland that used to be Michigan.

I'd give it a 10/10

And in case that doesn't convince you, there's a demo you can try out to get an idea of what the game is like.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definently one of the gems of Early Access.
A cruel survival game, the developers eye for details is very noticeable in the world, characters, items as well as the crafting system. With an atmosphere reminding of a great title like Fallout you can't go wrong.

It took me several attempts before I was able to survive more than a few days, the learning curve might seem steep but you need to be able to learn from your mistakes and work through that. Some times it can just be dumb luck, or bad luck, sometimes you learn a lesson (don't eat the wrong berries!)

Fight against the elements, your own needs, and the countless bandits & beasts that roam the wasteland.

As with all Early Access titles, beware that the game is under early development and can become subject to radical changes, re-balancing and wipes. I have yet to find any game-breaking bugs (or many other bugs for that matter) even tho I'm playing the latest beta version.

Will be very interesting to see the final product, best of luck to you Daniel :)

reviewText:
Spawned in.
Went to my right hex to some office buildings.
Found myself a Hunting Rifle with ammo.
Killed my first bandit.
Looted my first corpse.
Got myself a decent pair of boots, jeans and a hoodie.
I was living the dream.
Several days later.
I was thirsty.
I got dehydrated.
I panicked.
Jumped to hex to hex just to find water.
Only found water. Undrinkable water.
I died from dehydration.

[insert obvious meme here]

reviewText: Brilliant game with a real feeling of fear and post apocalyptic gameplay. The problem with the game is that it is ridiculously chance derived and geared towards grinding. Yes I understand it is a rogue like game" but it takes the worst elements of rogue like and runs under them with a banner off a cliff. Practically the only way to play this game for more then a few minutes is by save scumming through it but even with that its so tedious and repetitive that the novelty  behind this game wears off fast. The story-line is almost nonexistent and is stringed out like a carrot on a stick. Its sad because I want to like this game. It has all of the essential qualities of being an amazing game and had the developers spent a little more time working on it then this would have been one of my favorite games. Sadly they didn't spend the extra time and this is just kind of a mediocre game that has some cool ideas behind it that aren't fully developed."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(EDIT: Fixed a terrible typo that changed the meaning of one sentence into the very opposite.)

Even during its beta stage NEO Scavenger feels like a completed and a released game. It can be intense (provided you have the imagination), it can be (actually it WILL be) evil and it can be forgiving (for a brief second before you run into a pack of dogmen who rip you apart).

NEO is also ridiculously cheap for it's value. Of course, I'm not trying to encourage a higher price, I'm just thanking Daniel for his reasonable pricing. (Take that Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes)

I can't recommend this enough. After getting the game I sunk a ridiculous amount of time into it in a single weekend. I recommend starting off completely blind. No wikis. No gameplay videos. Just jump in. After dying horribly a few times, you can begin checking a few things out from the wiki. OH and I URGE you to read all the messages at the bottom of the screen during combat (you can click the box to expand). Then just let your imagination fly and get all the horribly violent moments carved deep into your brains. If your imagination is anything like mine, you're gonna find this game to be one of the most ruthlessly violent games you've played and it doesn't even graphically show you any of the scenes.

Now, I understand this is not a game for everyone. If you don't enjoy reading a lot of text, that is not a reason to stay away. You don't have to read any of it. But if you don't enjoy slow paced, the original Fallout-like games with survival and tension, you might as well stay away. But if you know someone who likes that kind of stuff, please, tell them about NEO Scavenger.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Half roguelike, half text adventure RPG/adventure game, NEO Scavenger is definitely something new.  I picked it up after watching a couple of YouTube videos, planned on playing for a few minutes, and found myself trying to beat a bandit to death with a rock while I coughed up blood.  Limping away from the fight, I died moments later from acute blood loss.

It's a brutal but phenomenal game.  It relies heavily on your own imagination which, in my opinion, makes it that much more powerful.  It is one of the only games that captures the bleakness and terror of the situation.  One moment you're strutting along with a shotgun in hand, a smile on your face, and the next, you're panicking because you drank contaminated water.  You're sick, coughing, vomiting, and it's all over.

Phenomental, wonderful game and a great replayable experience.  Just be prepared to lose because it is a *difficult* game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlthough the graphics can be out right disgusting and the learning curve in the game is at an all time high. With countless early game deaths due to hypothermia or a nasty encounter. If you are willing to stick around to find that right strategy, this one has quickly become an addictive addition to my collection. I wholeheartedly suggest to the fans of survival games to give this one a try at the very least the demo. For the faint of heart or quick tempered steer clear. This title is full of conditions that will have even the heartiest adventure tripping over your own two feet.(in some cases quite literally) But if you are looking for a new challenge to this genre you will make a happy new find in this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Cheesy game play? Not really at all. Graphics and interface are not 'high speed' but the game is about choices, and not letting yourself get beat down. 11 hours I made it. Oh joy! Very inventory management intensive. If you want to keep something better figure out how to fit it in whatever you may have at hand. Pretty cool crafting so far to. I made a shiv and a spear pretty quick. I also figured out to sacrifice a sleeping man to escape a death right at the start. This is not a forgiving game either. I got knocked down and then beaten to death by two guys and was not able to get up and defend myself. Ouch.
Pretty neat little distraction here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(EDIT: Fixed a terrible typo that changed the meaning of one sentence into the very opposite.)

Even during its beta stage NEO Scavenger feels like a completed and a released game. It can be intense (provided you have the imagination), it can be (actually it WILL be) evil and it can be forgiving (for a brief second before you run into a pack of dogmen who rip you apart).

NEO is also ridiculously cheap for it's value. Of course, I'm not trying to encourage a higher price, I'm just thanking Daniel for his reasonable pricing. (Take that Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes)

I can't recommend this enough. After getting the game I sunk a ridiculous amount of time into it in a single weekend. I recommend starting off completely blind. No wikis. No gameplay videos. Just jump in. After dying horribly a few times, you can begin checking a few things out from the wiki. OH and I URGE you to read all the messages at the bottom of the screen during combat (you can click the box to expand). Then just let your imagination fly and get all the horribly violent moments carved deep into your brains. If your imagination is anything like mine, you're gonna find this game to be one of the most ruthlessly violent games you've played and it doesn't even graphically show you any of the scenes.

Now, I understand this is not a game for everyone. If you don't enjoy reading a lot of text, that is not a reason to stay away. You don't have to read any of it. But if you don't enjoy slow paced, the original Fallout-like games with survival and tension, you might as well stay away. But if you know someone who likes that kind of stuff, please, tell them about NEO Scavenger.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a good idea to play the demo before you because the UI is a bit unique and can be off-putting. But for fans of the genre, this game is a must have. The sense of elation you feel when you scavenge through a crumbling apartment building and find a crowbar with a strap already affixed is just overwhelming.

voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic game.

Neo Scavenger sets out to do what many RPGs attempt, but often times get caught up in the mechanics of their own genre and fail to pull off. Every decision you make in Neo Scavenger echoes into your immediate future, often times setting you up for a failure that, with practice, you can foresee and avoid. It's just so well designed, I can find only a few flaws, and those can easily be ironed out before the game is finished.

Tons of content, easy to pick up, lots of fun strategic decisions, and best of all an intriguing story that makes you want to keep taking the more dangerous path just to find out more.

reviewText:
One of the finest post-apocalyptic roguelikes I've ever had the chance to play. Think Wasteland meets Dayz, with a dash of old-school text games like Zork. You won't be disappointed.

Pros:
-Unique storyline, with unforgiving decision making
-Brutally realistic survivalist scenarios
-Roguelike character creation guarantees variegated playthroughs
-Retro UI with innovative and intuitive item system
-Unpredictable gameplay keeps replay value high
-Permadeath = high-stakes

Cons:
-Prepare to die. Often.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf there is one of all the games i own that i can recommend, it's this one. Gonna assume you know the basics of it already from other sources, but if you're here to see if it's worth the price, the answer is YES. It's not only the best survival game on the market at this time, with a kickass story and setting to back up it's mechanics. But the sheer breadth of choices and the complexity of it's systems also makes it a generator of some amazing stories. Many a time are the retelling of the fates of some of my characters as entertaining as the time i spent playing them.

reviewText:
NEO scavenger is, without a doubt, the best surprise I've got through Humble Bundle. What at first seemed a little interesting survival game turned out to be a massive and addictive experience, with the most detailed survival mechanics you've ever seen (except maybe Project Zomboid).

In NEO Scavenger, death is considered a sure thing, the question is how long you will last for. Survive the cold, survive the wounds. Survive the infection, survive the unboiled water you were forced to drink because you had no way to make a fire. Survive the blisters you got because you hadn't found boots yet, while a dogman chases you. Survive the poisoning you got eating unidentified mushrooms. And worst of all, survive the people (NPCs) who want what you've managed to gather.

The world has unique lore, setting a post-apocalyptic world with paranormal phenomenons happening left and right, but extremely well presented, gradually giving you the information, which is spread through conversations, pieces of newspapers and others.

The atmosphere is similar(ly angsty) to those of Dark Souls, or EVE online, but more personal and centered around the desperate situation your character wakes up into, like Spec Ops: The Line.

The combat is quite simple and brutal: He who connects the first hit usually wins. This enforces a visceral and all-or-nothing mindset, with no place for holding resources back, and a shoot first
date: ask questions later" policy that makes you question your own acts as a player.\n\nBoth combat and map gameplay are turn-based
recommended: and reward thinking carefully about your next move
hoursPlayed: since the game works with permanent iron man mode (dying deletes the save file) to ensure that you're adequately kept on your toes.\n\nOverall
voteText: this is the best survival game I've ever played
helpfulPercent: and definitely the best one-man-made game out there:\n10/10"

reviewText:
One of the best roguelike experiences I've encountered, everything about this game is lovable and enjoyable, though in the beginning it can be very unforgiving. After you start you (or at least I did) will die many times from freezing without knowing what to do about it. Later you realise what you should do (or google it) and you get into the game a lot. There is quite a lot to explore, although the game could have a lot more content than it's having. However considering that it's not a big project and not many people are working on it, it's understandable.

Still, the price is quite high for what you get. It has a lot of replayability to a certain point, but after you reach that point and explore it all, there is nothing more to do. Updates bring something new quite often, but it's not really enough to keep you playing. I would advise buying it on at least 70% sale, or in a bundle or something.

8/10 Would join blue frogs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fresh take on the old rouge-like with great new game play systems that integrate seamlessly into the genre we know and love.

The exploratory gameplay is engaging and nerve-wracking at the same time, and the unpredictable nature of events in the game means you'll spend much of your time simply trying to plan ahead for every contingency. This coupled with the constant threat of permanent death creates a very engaging experience.

You never quite know what will happen once you step out of the Cryo Facility.  It truly defines survival, a lot of times on fresh starts I'd freeze to death on the first night since I couldn't find proper clothing, now that's realistic. There's a lot of potential here and I can't wait to see what the devs do with it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NEO Scavenger is the best roguelike to grace steam in some time. It's not about grinding, leveling up or anything like that. It's far more of a roguelike survival simulation. Only unlike Waywards island sim this game is more akin to the movie The Road or th S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series.

It's desperateand meaningful combat involves you sneaking around, pulling people down, parrying, stabbing, swinging and doing everything you can to win. While a win feels great, the person you're facing is often in the same shoes as you.

As for graphics everything is nicely drawn. Icons are easy to see and understand, the world is big but easy to navigate, the hand drawn figures range from average to awesome. It's not the best looking game but it's got a gritty atmosphere about it and it works great with the music.

As for the sim part, this game just shines. Plastic bags will rip and you'll lose items, certain items can't be put into shopping carts because of the wholes in the frame, you'll be dumping pills out of small pill containers and putting them into larger ones so you can carry more.

For a turn based game played on a hex grid, this is game can really get to you. I definitely suggest picking it up.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you ever wanted a game that blends Oregon Trail and Fallout but with total emphasis on player response-ability (yes I mean response-ability) then go try the demo of this game right now. Although brutal from the start (I survived 3 hours my first playthrough), the more you play this game and the more time you devote to figuring out what skills/items/reactions will help you survive depending on the given situation (Hint: run) the more satisfying it is when you reach the point of gun-toting, berry-eating, sleeping-bag-sleeping, Dogman slaying badass, ONLY to die of diarrhea (RIP colon). And in the total stupor of how did... that... why?" begin another playthrough and start the whole brutal endeavor all over again- BUT this time ready to defeat the mutated Detroit Diarrhea of the future with the knowledge gleaned from your frothy death (Hint #2: boil your damn water). Excellent! Fine! Stupendous! Here we go again! Thanks to procedurally generated environments

reviewText:
NEO Scavenger is a very different game. I haven't played many like it, and certainly not any that I have enjoyed as much. It's a complicatedly simple game. It nearly masters survival against the elements, finding and cleaning water to drink, gathering plants for food or beating a deer to death with your bare hands for food.

It's style will put a lot of people off. It is a text game at it's descriptive and story core, something I am absolutely fine with, coupled with a hex based pixelated landscape. The controls are entirely mouse based or a combination of mouse and keyboard, and while it can seem strange and complex at first, a few playthroughs and you'll master them.

Another thing that will put people off is it's genre. It is that, no common, rouge-like." When you die

I must admit, I was skeptical at first about this game and judged it by its cover; after having played it, I was immediately sucked in. The best way I can describe its INSANELY complex mechanics and UNIQUE style of gameplay is like if Fallout's and DayZ's scavenging with some crafting skills and the Lunch Money" card game combat (turn based location specific).

Must have!

Bonus if you are from Detroit!

10/10"
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best survival games I have played; where it's a dog eats dog world. Hunger sets in if you don't consume food, you can die from dehydration, freeze to death, bleed to death, die from infection and poison; the odds are stacked against you. However, the same goes for everyone else in Neo Scavenger, as well. It isn't like other games, where they severly penalize you but the conditions does not effect the enemy. Far from it, scavengers you find along the way can bleed to their demise and freeze and perish in the cold if they have no clothing, just like the way you can in the given conditions.


If you pick this game up, be prepared to scream at times, and die countless more. Each death comes with learning to play better, and the learning curve is extremely steep. This game is literally based on Marxism, and it truly is a brutal, unforgiving atmosphere. Do not underestimate the enemy, and if you encounter two or more at once, do not be frugal. It's better to use that ammunition and live another day, than die and start over. Gear up and learn how to survive; and good luck.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A pretty outstanding game.

It's a hexagonbase survival strategy game, that stresses on finding equipment to endure the elements, finding food, water, and medicine to survive. In a post apocalyptic world, it's you and you alone that must brave the outside world where anything could be your enemy.

It's a scavanger game, you loot anything you are able to and keep anything useful, anything from nuts and bolts to nightvision goggles and assault rifles. Eventually you will have a character that you have put a bit of time and effort into creating, this is where the game gets fun.

I really enjoy this game. It just recently came out a few months ago, I believe, and the dev is already coming out with patches, and helpful fixes towards the game. So, there's always new stuff to look forward to.

If you play scavanging games, and you enjoy the satisfaction of trying to survive as long as you can.
Then, I suggest you give this title a try.
It even has a demo; if you are still unsure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NEO Scavenger now has my full recommendation.

This game has some deep tactical roots to it. A turned based rogue-like where you start off in the most startling position of weakness I could possibly imagine. “Scavenger” is the name of the game but this key aspect and function serves as a means to an end, and that end is survival.

You wake up in a cryogenic facility with nothing of use but a hospital gown, medical bracelet. You're soon attacked by a supernatural creature, setting the tone for the brutal reality of survival, which seems to be the biggest note of the game. Notice I didn’t mention any shoes or memories. You’re barefoot and it’s autumn. No way to go through life in my humble opinion. I guess there’s a story about finding your identity or finding out what happened to the world.

Sounds interesting, right? Like “28 Days Later” meets “DayZ”. I couldn’t tell you, because basically I’ve spent my hours just trying to survive against... get ready for it...

Starvation. Food is scarce. I once savored a small packet of crackers for sustenance. I recently died trying to hunt a dangerous creature in what felt like a very realistic and thought out exchange in combat.

Hydration. Water is not as scarce, but takes up storage space and the effects of dehydration can onset quickly leaving you weaker to take on the rigors of survival and ultimately lead to death.

Hypothermia. It always seems cold and rainy. One play-through I traveled west for 12 hours and died of hypothermia desperately trying to find some degree of shelter or warmth.

Brain damage and severe blood loss. Some people seem to be opportunists in this new and horrifying setting, attacking you on sight. You can try to reason with them or beat them to death or submission. Either way combat has to be dealt with or avoided one way or another. There are also inhumane beasts, such as the dogman who(that?) recently severed an artery in my leg, taking a fluke victory in what was described to me as brutal combat.

The turned based combat plays out very interestingly, giving you often unique choices based on your surroundings, tools and skill set. In addition to normal attacks with your weaponry you often have different tactical options in a fight, like a trip or a head-butt. Leaving your opponent stunned and vulnerable is a key to winning conflicts and staying healthy.

Wounds need attention and in a very animalistic way you need to learn that just because you can best a being in mortal combat it doesn’t necessarily mean he can be your prey.  The spoils of war are all well and good but damn well better be worth the cost of an open wound or wounded limb.
Luckily there seems to be a wide array of technology, pharmaceuticals and med-kits to be found in your mysterious surroundings, everything seems to have something more to it. There's a vast world of crafting, trapping and other skills I've only touched the surface of. Hacking with a laptop can be far more effective than hacking with a cleaver.

Storage plays as big of a roll as anything I have mentioned thus far. I really enjoy the vast inventory options and the various challenges that arrive. The tools available to you in moving your life supporting cargo are just as varied. Plastic bags can be used as a light and spacious backpack but they quickly deteriorate under such use, a true backpack can handle much more rigors. Sleds can be used to drag your sleeping bag and other supplies but is outclassed by a modified shopping cart as a vehicle.

Light sources can play a big part in safe scavenging, night time or not. Lighters run out of butane though, and flashlights need batteries. You often consume some of your items durability upon use as you scavenge for that rare useful weapon and equally sparse ammunition.

There are some hiccups in this surprisingly immersive experience, like a lack of a local leaderboard and tracking or rating of your statistics and progress. The game doesn’t seem to integrate with windows well on start-up, but this is easily fixable in the settings. The aural potential of this game seems unrealized and the atmospheric tune that plays throughout doesn’t do enough for me. The lack of sound just about the only thing holding me back from having a more immersed experience.

The slightly crude graphics and the fact that it is a Java game may be off putting to some, but those willing to look past the amateur feel will be rewarded with a view into this game’s deep, brutal, intelligent soul. The sense and reality of a true, terrifying post-apocalyptic survival setting seems fully represented. Made by Blue Bottle Games, which from what I can tell is just one dude, this frisky indie title feels like a true labor of love towards the bleak reality of our impending doom.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I discovered this game through a blog post linked through Kerbal Space Program about how failure can be a good element of a game. Obviously, this raises a big flag about the difficulty of the game. I enjoy realism and brutal challenge in games though, so I investigated and tried the demo on their website. I loved it. It's basically a classic rogue-like, but takes place in post-apocalyptic michigan.

I've died from the cold
I've died from infection
I've died from looters
I've died from thirst
I've only played for a few hours and already chalked up an impressive range of tragic ends. Each time you die, you take away a valuable lesson on survival in the games harsh, unforgiving world. Any fans of difficult rogue-likes or open-world adventure games should DEFINITELY check it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now I can't say much about the end game bits (If there even is an End game this game seems to last forever) but what I can say about this new update today, is it is WHOLEFULY welcomed. This update makes it so much better, gives a better balance to the beginning skills and some thing alittle bit less noticable is the beginning area is now dotted with more cities and towns which really increase your chances of finding some cloths or a backpack which are damnedfully welcomed. Now these changes do make the game slightly easier but hell this was probably the hardest game I own in my library. Now it's only the hardest game I own still. Lemme say how hard this bloody game is, it's harder than probably all the Darksoul bosses put in to one fight. I mean the environment will kill you, if a Bad Motha doesn't beat your brains out while you sleep, or the infamous shadow that just makes you explode basically.

Even for a early access game I must be honest I feel like I'm getting a full game that is complete. I rarely find bugs, or any imbalaces. The Dev does a AAA job of keeping up with the community and the game. I've had a few early access games and by far this Dev really takes care of this game, like all devs should.

So if you're a fan of Hexagon RPG, Survival, Mystery, Action, Adventure, Strategy, Turnbased Fun... or even one of those applies to you, I'd highly recommend getting this game.

For $10 you honestly cannot go wrong with this game.

10/10 Would get stoned to death again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A nice premise - old style hex adventure, but with the usual apocalyse scenario.

Its far from easy, for example anyone thinking of rushing headlong against mobs the moment you start should think again or you will die, and it will happen often. Sneak around scavenging for clothing, weapons... craft those bits of junk into something useable. Then go out again - you'll still get killed, but perhaps less often. This is a game of learning and trial & error. You will learn as you die. And you will learn as you survive. Its something of a slow burner. You WILL come back to it after a period of frustration. It'll sit there somewhere in your mind, suggesting you have another go - maybe this time...

Permadeath has to be in the game or would essentially ruin the story, and essentially this is the driving force - this game can be replayed with different information based on your skillset - perhaps some things that would be hidden would be revealed.

I feel some things that need improving - crafting for example is good, but would be best if it remembered every combination you'd come up with from previous games (rather like the old son of in the old rogue type games. This has some previous recipes but not many, and trying to remember them all yourself is absurd.

Also something that (I think) needs changing to a degree is the way loot is calculated - many times you can obtain a hoard from scavenging with almost no chance to gain anything, but then you can repeatedly find nothing when you have a good chance. Certain skills improve or reduce this, but I think too much in some cases.

Basically here is a potentially good game, which needs many more refinements before it can really be considered complete.

I enjoy this sort of game, but I really wonder if I'm actually anything better than totally rubbish at them. The fact is that despite any faults - any time you have what you deem to be a completely unfair death or when you were just starting to do well for once then along comes... a big nasty monster... at least you have the knowledge of what doesnt work next time, or a different skill to pick - maybe you'll endure the early multitude of deaths and finish the game - perhaps I really am rubbish at it, maybe it (the game) needs balancing, or maybe it always will be just a tad too hard.

In conclusion:
I'd play it more if I didnt die as often, if I got to see slightly more of the story.

All too often you go through the initial stages then die in a low level battle. Perhaps if you were just left sometimes with your stuff robbed - at least you had a little chance...

7/10 (with potential to be 9/10)

**SPOILER ALERT**

Then I tried cheating using a mod to add every skill but it had lost its charm because of this becoming too easy.  I dont want a walkthough,  want a hard playthrough but please not a hundred of them, I dont have the time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery engrossing survival game where it actually feels like you struggle to survive. You have to watch what you eat and drink, make sure you’re clothed properly, and as the title suggest, scavenge the world for supplies and materials. Every time you play it's different, and it can come down to skill and some luck. There are interesting skills that provide you with a variety of crafting options that may otherwise be unavailable, or perks such as the ability to find more loot, get better information on your medical state, or craft certain items. Pretty good story (although I haven't gotten very far because I die a lot :D) Highly recommend to anyone who is into more hardcore survival games. The interface seemed strange at first, but after a few tries the combat and exploration became very engrossing, which I was not expecting from the screenshots. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think you have to be a little bit careful putting a blanket 'recommend' or not on a title like this.

This is most defninitely not for everyone.

If you are willing to 'do your homework', i.e., read the wiki, watch a few youtube vids, read the forums, ask a few questions there, then you are certainly in a position to find what I did.

What I found was the most addictive, delightfully absorbing, strategic and tactical role-playing, survival game. It reminded me of my favourite gaming experience of all time, that of Fallout 2.

However, the user interface, is not friendly nor intuitive. This is one step up from Dwarf Fortress. There's a lot of inventory micromanagement, and that involves a lot of clicks.

There is a demo, which minus some items, is very similar to the main game, so I see no need for a long review.

Just ask 'am I willing to put some effort in here?'. If you do a bit of homework, you will be very much rewarded.

More of this sort of thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is unlike any I have played in the last two decades. I recommend it to anyone who wants a turn-based hex RPG. Set in a post-apocolyptic Lovecraftian Michigan, your character emerges from a crygenic vat to step into a race against time. You can die from dehydration, starvation, disease  and hypothermia, in addition to wounds inflicted by the various denizens surrounding the Motor City's wastelands.

This hard setting is further amplified by the decision not to include a leveling system. Each time you play, you learn more about the game mechanics and possibilities. You can augment your character with four of a dozen advantages, as well as about six disadvantages. Thes combination of these influence your play style, as some opportunities only present themselves to those with a given trait.

For those who love to play first-person shooter RPG" as murder hobos
date: this is not the game for you. It is more reminiscent of games from the late 1980s and early 1990s in that it tells its story in a piecemeal fashion with only one Rouge-like save option. While you can engage in combat
hoursPlayed: scavanging and crafting reveal much more of the story
voteText: and further contribute to the desperation as you try to unravel not only how you came to be cycled out of the cryogenics tank
helpfulPercent: but also what happened to create this near-future landscape.\n\nExpect to die a lot. And enjoy it."

It's an early access game that's been tons of fun to fall into.  There seems to be plenty of content initially, and the game author keeps adding more at a good clip.

I like that the game has a 'take no prisoners' attitude.  One minute you're riding high, cart full of goods and a shot gun with *at least* three shells, next thing you know someone hit you in the head with a spear and you're bleeding out.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game intrigued me the minute I saw it.  I would always play Zork in a huddle with friends, but I was always the only one to beat it.  This led me to be fully engrossed in text based games for years to come.  NEO Scavenger takes text heavy elements that remind me of Zork.  These come into play during the small, but quite enjoyable narrative that the player builds into their game.  The exploration and post-apocalyptic atmosphere also brought back memories of Fallout, but much more serious.  This is by no means a bad thing though because players want a very realistic experience, full of imagery, when playing a text heavy game.  This realism is also extremely prevalent during combat with so many options to choose from depending on skills, gear, etc.  However skills and gear can also heavily limit combat.  This helps the player get a feeling for their character better when role-playing a smart, but incredibly weak character.  This game gets a 9/10 from me because even though it's in my list of personal favorites, it has some faults that limit the game.  These are noticeable if too many mistakes are made on a run, lack of devotion causing boredom, or the always prevalent difficulty curve of rogue-likes.  However, I would recommend this to anyone, regardless of these minor issues, due to the shear number of appealing qualities this game holds that a vast majority of gamers, looking for a new flavored splash of adventure in their games, can enjoy.

I spent a lot of time looking for a good scavenging/crafting/surviving experience. Since stalker: call of pripyat I felt kind of left in the bench, but Neo scavenger totaly have potential for it! It feels like actual surviving, having to find food, clothes, shelter, water, tools, weapons, decide if you run or fight in an encounter, craft things etc. every mistakes can be paid the high price, the global experience is impressively convincing!

The game's really hard tho, I keep dying in so many different ways, which is great as surviving shouldn't be easy, but the permadeath makes it really hard on the player, you barely start to get some good stuffs and die to start from the beghining again. It's really frustrating, but the difficulty of the game make it so deliciously painful ^^

The game is still on developement so criticizing is probably prematured, but i'd like to signal that the rarity and price of ammunitions makes it unworthy to equip anything else than melee weapons, also (maybe it's a bug) when the cart broke i lost all my stuffs inside on many occasions, which doesn't make sens, as if the cart broke the stuffs shouldn't just disapear and be on the ground for me to save what i can... And last thing, the food/water mechanism isn't really logic, as you'll starve almost as fast as you'll get dehydrated, eating 50kg of berries will feed you for barely a few hours and they're pretty hard to find when you need them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok so this game is ... addictive.

A nice post apocalyptic setup with one of the most detailed crafting systems I've ever seen. Also the game makes real use of the character skills, just like in old school RPG's - ain't got melee skill? Well, ain't gonna craft the best melee weapons, for example.

As it is some kind of rouge like, there's no saving to be safe, it's just go for it and hope that you won't mess up, which leads to some pretty frustrating moments but also is part of the addictive character of the game. Closed the game more then one time during my 15 ingame hours but came back every time to start a new character.

The combat system is kind of strange in the first few tries but as soon as you get the hang of it, it is really fun. It works turn based and you choose your actions as the enemies choose theirs, after that the outcome is shown in a textfield with lots of pretty brutal stuff, from arrows to the knee to wolffangs to your face.

The graphic is not up to date, instead it is real outdated but this game is not about graphics, it's about imagination. Many encounters contain lots and lots of written text (remember Fallout 1/2 or Baldurs Gate conversations? - you won't find those conversations but massive ambient text).

Features:
- nice ambient text
- great crafting system, starting from making glas shards out of bottles over crafting armor from hides and furs to upgrade weapons with scopes for example
- huge bunch of neat items with degeneration
- deep skillsystem with skills giving options on encounters (but skills are chosen on character creation and can't be trained)
- big range of enemies starting from cannibal gangs over strange mutants up to paramilitary townguards (if you decide to attack them)
- extensive character needs, from hunger and thirst over induced pain to warmth (yes, you can freeze and expect to do so often in the beginning)
-rouge like: saving only by leaving the game, a dead character stays dead but a nice little statistic when died shows some of the players accomplishments
- one of the most stable early access games I've ever played with a range of features and stuff that outruns some released games by far
- big, randomly created (open) world with some points of interest
- devs active on steam forum

If you like challenging games which are more about ambient then shiny graphics, show those devs some love and give it a try (there's also a demo which I highly recommend to play to be sure this kind of game suites you).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of Steam's best hidden gems.

The game feels like a cross between Fallout, DayZ, and even a little Project Zomboid sprinkled in. The game is really difficult yet it manages to make the experience fun. And when I say difficult I mean difficult, it's not a question of if you will die, it's more of a question WHEN will you die.

You start in a cryo facility completely nude, save for a hospital gown. This is a problem because un-like other survival games the temperature is a very important part of the game. If you're not wearing multiple layers of shirts as well as pants and shoes you will freeze to death minutes after you start.

The health system is really neat. It requires you to bandage each individual cut you receive. There are also injuries like broken bones that are severely crippling because of how little room you are given to carry things. The inventory system gives you a couple options: Carry it in your hands or if you have a backpack you can put it in there. Aside from that you can put things in your pants. However not even the largest backpack gives you a ton of room so every limb needs to be functioning for you to survive. There is also a range of illness that you can catch. They can be related to the cold, an infection from a cut, drinking/eating tainted water and food (respectively), and a whole host of other diseases that I've yet to experience.

TL;DR The health system is pretty intricate and requires dilligantly repairing yourself if you're going to live as well as being sanitary.

There are bandits and other monsters that prevent you from getting to comfortable. The combat in Neo Scavenger is also pretty realistic. If you fall over or get stunned it could be it for you. Or maybe not. Not everyone in this game is a blackbelt and the majority of people, including you will often stumble in combat or miss their attacks. In-fact even just charging at your enemy is a risky move becuse you could trip and open yourself up to being stomped. Guns in this game are well done and you won't become invincible if you can get one. They are decently common, however, ammo is not. You may be lucky to find maybe 6 rounds that fit into your gun. But guns are not completely uselss, though. A single bullet can end a fight. Being shot in the torso is enough to make you fall over and possibly passout, destined to either be looted and wake up naked and bleeding with your guts strewn about or to get stomped once your opponent has reached you. Bullets will also cripple/break bones so being shot in the leg or arm might not be directly fatal but the resulting infection/unability to carry things could be.

TL;DR Combat is also really realistic and fair (except for when the Bad Muthas are ganging up on you).

Crafting is also, unsurprisingly decently realistic. There isn't tons of stuff you can craft but what you can craft is realistic. For instance if you want to butcher the bandit you just killed, cook him up, and finally eat him there are several ways to do so. Unlike some games where you must have a certain tool this game allows you to use all sorts of simmilar tools to do the same thing. When you're butchering the dead bandit you can use nearly every sharp object in the game to complete this task. Crafting also will occasionally require that you have specific traits that are set up at the beggining of the game. There are a few vehicles that can be made/found and can be used to pull some of the crap you're carrying at a penalty to speed.

TL;DR There isn't much to say. Crafting is realistic but there isn't tons to make.

There is no story right now, so there's not much to say about that.


Bad stuff:

The user-interface is a bit messy.

There isn't much NPC-Player interaction other than killing eachother or NPCs acting indignant when you ask them stuff about the world.

Should you buy this game?

Yes! Even though it isn't completed and there is no story it's a fun game. The devs seem interested in completing this game so it's a safe bet that they won't abandon the project if they make bank on EA. I'm honestly surprised that more people haven't bought this game. Fans of Fallout and survival games will enjoy this game thoroughly. However, if you are not interested in games being realistic and you hate non-3D, mostly text-based, and not FPS games then don't buy this.

Rating: 9/10 Buy it.

TL;DR  It's a good game. If you're still not convinced try the demo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I discovered this game through a blog post linked through Kerbal Space Program about how failure can be a good element of a game. Obviously, this raises a big flag about the difficulty of the game. I enjoy realism and brutal challenge in games though, so I investigated and tried the demo on their website. I loved it. It's basically a classic rogue-like, but takes place in post-apocalyptic michigan.

I've died from the cold
I've died from infection
I've died from looters
I've died from thirst
I've only played for a few hours and already chalked up an impressive range of tragic ends. Each time you die, you take away a valuable lesson on survival in the games harsh, unforgiving world. Any fans of difficult rogue-likes or open-world adventure games should DEFINITELY check it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now I can't say much about the end game bits (If there even is an End game this game seems to last forever) but what I can say about this new update today, is it is WHOLEFULY welcomed. This update makes it so much better, gives a better balance to the beginning skills and some thing alittle bit less noticable is the beginning area is now dotted with more cities and towns which really increase your chances of finding some cloths or a backpack which are damnedfully welcomed. Now these changes do make the game slightly easier but hell this was probably the hardest game I own in my library. Now it's only the hardest game I own still. Lemme say how hard this bloody game is, it's harder than probably all the Darksoul bosses put in to one fight. I mean the environment will kill you, if a Bad Motha doesn't beat your brains out while you sleep, or the infamous shadow that just makes you explode basically.

Even for a early access game I must be honest I feel like I'm getting a full game that is complete. I rarely find bugs, or any imbalaces. The Dev does a AAA job of keeping up with the community and the game. I've had a few early access games and by far this Dev really takes care of this game, like all devs should.

So if you're a fan of Hexagon RPG, Survival, Mystery, Action, Adventure, Strategy, Turnbased Fun... or even one of those applies to you, I'd highly recommend getting this game.

For $10 you honestly cannot go wrong with this game.

10/10 Would get stoned to death again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A nice premise - old style hex adventure, but with the usual apocalyse scenario.

Its far from easy, for example anyone thinking of rushing headlong against mobs the moment you start should think again or you will die, and it will happen often. Sneak around scavenging for clothing, weapons... craft those bits of junk into something useable. Then go out again - you'll still get killed, but perhaps less often. This is a game of learning and trial & error. You will learn as you die. And you will learn as you survive. Its something of a slow burner. You WILL come back to it after a period of frustration. It'll sit there somewhere in your mind, suggesting you have another go - maybe this time...

Permadeath has to be in the game or would essentially ruin the story, and essentially this is the driving force - this game can be replayed with different information based on your skillset - perhaps some things that would be hidden would be revealed.

I feel some things that need improving - crafting for example is good, but would be best if it remembered every combination you'd come up with from previous games (rather like the old son of in the old rogue type games. This has some previous recipes but not many, and trying to remember them all yourself is absurd.

Also something that (I think) needs changing to a degree is the way loot is calculated - many times you can obtain a hoard from scavenging with almost no chance to gain anything, but then you can repeatedly find nothing when you have a good chance. Certain skills improve or reduce this, but I think too much in some cases.

Basically here is a potentially good game, which needs many more refinements before it can really be considered complete.

I enjoy this sort of game, but I really wonder if I'm actually anything better than totally rubbish at them. The fact is that despite any faults - any time you have what you deem to be a completely unfair death or when you were just starting to do well for once then along comes... a big nasty monster... at least you have the knowledge of what doesnt work next time, or a different skill to pick - maybe you'll endure the early multitude of deaths and finish the game - perhaps I really am rubbish at it, maybe it (the game) needs balancing, or maybe it always will be just a tad too hard.

In conclusion:
I'd play it more if I didnt die as often, if I got to see slightly more of the story.

All too often you go through the initial stages then die in a low level battle. Perhaps if you were just left sometimes with your stuff robbed - at least you had a little chance...

7/10 (with potential to be 9/10)

**SPOILER ALERT**
Leave the talisman alone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why I have stopped playing NEO Scavenger.

First of all congratulations on creating this game.  Its a very very good game. This is the first and possibly only review I have ever been compelled to write on steam and its something to be said for the quality of this game that I want to save this game for me and not put it in my discard pile.

I hesitated about giving this a yes review for the reason that there is no save function.  I get what you are trying to do with death being death however after spending over one hundred hours and near twenty or thirty attempts just to get as far as the gate of detroit (once)... in the last three cases doing nothing but hunting and hiding in a forest making leather armour (mod?) for nigh on twenty hours of play time only to be slaughtered by two dog men half an hour after setting out for the city then doing the same thing in another game, spending this time ten hours (of real life time)  in a forest making leather armour only to be slaughtered by three men as soon as I left the forest not even being able to run away and then doing the same thing, ten hours in a forest hunting and making armour,  only to be slaughtered while I slept without even waking up even though I had multiple noise traps in place.  Then I tried cheating using a mod to add every skill but it had lost its charm because of this becoming too easy.  I dont want a walkthough,  want a hard playthrough but please not a hundred of them, I dont have the time.

I have stopped playing this game because I dont have this sort of time to spend to get no where in a game.  I choose not to play again to try and get somewhere in the plot only then to later get slaughtered having spent a hundred hours progressing the plot and have to start all over again.  I want to play it through and I commend you for having this idea to have this when your dead your dead" idea but I actually have a real life to survive in and I simply dont have time to spend too much of it locked into this game.

Yes
date: have an Iron man mode for the realism of the survival aspect of the game
recommended: but until there is a save function I will not be returning to this game.  I recommend this game to anyone who has a hundred hours to spend just to get out of the starting blocks.\n\nEDIT... I have changed this from NO to YES to NO to YES... Its too good not to reccomend.  And... then... I started another game... Dan... I hate you... I love you... I hate you... I love you... please add an iron man function your driving me insane."
