reviewText:
Early Access Review

With more than 30 hours of gametime, I can happily say that this game is awesome. Only a few games have ever really left me wanting to play a little more, and this is one of them.

That being said though, this game is brutal. One minute you are killing Bad Muthas left and right and the next moment your clawed to death by a Dogman, or shot by a high powered rifle. This game never lets you have it easy, and even if you think that you can survive forever, think again. I personally tried to fight the Detroit Megacity Gaurds, it didn't end well. I also took off the bronze talisman, just to see why I had it, that didn't end to well, either.

This game is one of the best survival games I've ever played, and I will continue to play this game long into the future. If you want to buy this game, you should.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery engrossing survival game where it actually feels like you struggle to survive. You have to watch what you eat and drink, make sure you’re clothed properly, and as the title suggest, scavenge the world for supplies and materials. Every time you play it's different, and it can come down to skill and some luck. There are interesting skills that provide you with a variety of crafting options that may otherwise be unavailable, or perks such as the ability to find more loot, get better information on your medical state, or craft certain items. Pretty good story (although I haven't gotten very far because I die a lot :D) Highly recommend to anyone who is into more hardcore survival games. The interface seemed strange at first, but after a few tries the combat and exploration became very engrossing, which I was not expecting from the screenshots. Highly recommended!

A fantastic game, a true retro feel. If you are looking for something with graphics this isnt the game. If you are looking to kill a bandit with a sharpend stick to loot him for a boot a crummy tshirt and a quarter full lighter then this is your game. The perma death system makes you take fewer risks (you know, actually trying to survive) The skill system is pretty good, though at the time of this review isnt fully implemented. The only thing i have against this game is if you use a cleaner like CC cleaner it will wipe your saved game. SO keep that in mind, you dont want to wipe your flash cache when playing this one. 9/10, would play again...if i wernt still keeping it in a window while i work.

Update 8/30/14 The game has been updated to have more enemies, more items, more story. Every addition is very cool. I've never seen an unfinished game that added things so quickly and so smoothly. They are really on adding content. This is fast becoming one of my favorite games of all time. Best 10 bucks i ever spent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, I've bought quite a few games this year, and with the year almost over, I can say this is my favorite this year. Yes, it handily beats Bioshock Infinte in my book.

Sure, I love Post Apoc, I love turn based, and I especially love a game that requires real thinking and planning, so it hits many of my buttons. Still amazes me that a small team like this can beat a game with a $100 million budget like Infinate.

I just hope that they keep up on improving this game and make it into a true classic. The main things missing are better UI, more of everything, and ironing out a few bugs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think you have to be a little bit careful putting a blanket 'recommend' or not on a title like this.

This is most defninitely not for everyone.

If you are willing to 'do your homework', i.e., read the wiki, watch a few youtube vids, read the forums, ask a few questions there, then you are certainly in a position to find what I did.

What I found was the most addictive, delightfully absorbing, strategic and tactical role-playing, survival game. It reminded me of my favourite gaming experience of all time, that of Fallout 2.

However, the user interface, is not friendly nor intuitive. This is one step up from Dwarf Fortress. There's a lot of inventory micromanagement, and that involves a lot of clicks.

There is a demo, which minus some items, is very similar to the main game, so I see no need for a long review.

Just ask 'am I willing to put some effort in here?'. If you do a bit of homework, you will be very much rewarded.

More of this sort of thing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is unlike any I have played in the last two decades. I recommend it to anyone who wants a turn-based hex RPG. Set in a post-apocolyptic Lovecraftian Michigan, your character emerges from a crygenic vat to step into a race against time. You can die from dehydration, starvation, disease  and hypothermia, in addition to wounds inflicted by the various denizens surrounding the Motor City's wastelands.

This hard setting is further amplified by the decision not to include a leveling system. Each time you play, you learn more about the game mechanics and possibilities. You can augment your character with four of a dozen advantages, as well as about six disadvantages. Thes combination of these influence your play style, as some opportunities only present themselves to those with a given trait.

For those who love to play first-person shooter RPG" as murder hobos
date: this is not the game for you. It is more reminiscent of games from the late 1980s and early 1990s in that it tells its story in a piecemeal fashion with only one Rouge-like save option. While you can engage in combat
hoursPlayed: scavanging and crafting reveal much more of the story
voteText: and further contribute to the desperation as you try to unravel not only how you came to be cycled out of the cryogenics tank
helpfulPercent: but also what happened to create this near-future landscape.\n\nExpect to die a lot. And enjoy it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You can, and you will die a hundered different ways. I spent hours just wandering through wilderness, trying to find something to warm myself, then I died because of unfiltered water. Another character was a survivalist, not a computer engineer type like the last one, so this time I had plenty of warmth, clean water(because I found cooking pot), food(human meat), and overall was a pretty badass. Died because of insatiable hunger for human meat.

PROS
Rich and deep game with content gradually incoming from devs, really nice post-apo rpg sim, that is a nice retro in post-apo genre.

CONS
Well... it's early access, so you know what that means. If you're not fan of post-apo, original Fallout games seemed too complicated and old-fashioned, but Fallout 3 was a nice fps for you... I have bad news for ya. If you however want to support devs, so they can continue with this game, and you don't mind that you're buying half empty bottle(with a hope that it will refill later), go for it.

Hours of fun, depth not seen in a long time, overall must have for fans of the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A solid good game, the style RPGs used to be, before all that skill-tree stuff. Combat is amazing, blow by blow, no numeral damage, just serious wounds. I found myself bashing a guy's limbs with a big rock until I finally hitted his head and he felt unconsciously to the floor. I then proceeded to smash his face in and steal his corpse.
Examples aside, this game is passed on post-apocalyptical world, it is focused on scavenging and exploring, and although I haven't progressed much on the storyline I found the game to be just the kind of hardcore I was looking for.
If you are into SURVIVAL, TURN-BASED, SCAVENGING and don't care about graphics, this game is worth checking out!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's an early access game that's been tons of fun to fall into.  There seems to be plenty of content initially, and the game author keeps adding more at a good clip.

I like that the game has a 'take no prisoners' attitude.  One minute you're riding high, cart full of goods and a shot gun with *at least* three shells, next thing you know someone hit you in the head with a spear and you're bleeding out.

It really makes you think twice about how you're going to play out each encounter, and there are real consquences for bad decisions.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game intrigued me the minute I saw it.  I would always play Zork in a huddle with friends, but I was always the only one to beat it.  This led me to be fully engrossed in text based games for years to come.  NEO Scavenger takes text heavy elements that remind me of Zork.  These come into play during the small, but quite enjoyable narrative that the player builds into their game.  The exploration and post-apocalyptic atmosphere also brought back memories of Fallout, but much more serious.  This is by no means a bad thing though because players want a very realistic experience, full of imagery, when playing a text heavy game.  This realism is also extremely prevalent during combat with so many options to choose from depending on skills, gear, etc.  However skills and gear can also heavily limit combat.  This helps the player get a feeling for their character better when role-playing a smart, but incredibly weak character.  This game gets a 9/10 from me because even though it's in my list of personal favorites, it has some faults that limit the game.  These are noticeable if too many mistakes are made on a run, lack of devotion causing boredom, or the always prevalent difficulty curve of rogue-likes.  However, I would recommend this to anyone, regardless of these minor issues, due to the shear number of appealing qualities this game holds that a vast majority of gamers, looking for a new flavored splash of adventure in their games, can enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent a lot of time looking for a good scavenging/crafting/surviving experience. Since stalker: call of pripyat I felt kind of left in the bench, but Neo scavenger totaly have potential for it! It feels like actual surviving, having to find food, clothes, shelter, water, tools, weapons, decide if you run or fight in an encounter, craft things etc. every mistakes can be paid the high price, the global experience is impressively convincing!

The game's really hard tho, I keep dying in so many different ways, which is great as surviving shouldn't be easy, but the permadeath makes it really hard on the player, you barely start to get some good stuffs and die to start from the beghining again. It's really frustrating, but the difficulty of the game make it so deliciously painful ^^

The game is still on developement so criticizing is probably prematured, but i'd like to signal that the rarity and price of ammunitions makes it unworthy to equip anything else than melee weapons, also (maybe it's a bug) when the cart broke i lost all my stuffs inside on many occasions, which doesn't make sens, as if the cart broke the stuffs shouldn't just disapear and be on the ground for me to save what i can... And last thing, the food/water mechanism isn't really logic, as you'll starve almost as fast as you'll get dehydrated, eating 50kg of berries will feed you for barely a few hours and they're pretty hard to find when you need them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is utterly amazing.  Don't be put off by the mildly ugly graphics.  You will forget them in no time.  What makes this game mind blowing is that it is a rogue-ish game with permadeath, yet it doesn't feel like it.  Sure, the first few times you play you are going to measure your lifespan in hours, but once you get the hang of it you realize that survival is all up to you and completely possible for very long periods of time.  I am writting this after burning a solid 6 hours on this game in a single sitting.  In that entire time I had thrills, upsets, and close calls, but never died.  This is a rougalike game to be sure, but don't let that cause you to run screaming.

The survival aspects of this game are absolutely awesome.  You find yourself searching for food and water, planning ahead, and deciding when it is worth a risky encounter.  There is no I am a bad guy" badge on people.  See a fellow stranger in the distance?  It is up to you if you want to use surprise to take out a possible threat

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI haven't reviewed anything on Steam yet, but I had to review NEO Scavenger because this game deserves so much praise. It completely caught me by surprise and is a great example of Early Access done right. I paid the $9.99 awhile ago and I felt it was completely worth it, and after the frequent updates and improvements, it definitely continues to be worth the money. While I do think the UI needs to be cleaned up a little and the story could be fleshed out more, NEO Scavenger is still a great game. From the crafting that is more than just there because a ton of games are including it, to the way it draws you in for one more turn, and then another, and then maybe another hour goes by, I couldn't say enough good things. There are some flaws and it isn't for everyone, but check out the demo and support a developer that does Early Access right. I've so far put nearly 30 hours into NEO Scavenger and I'll definitely be adding to that number as time goes on
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NEO Scavenger is a rogue-like survival game that was originally made in Flash.
You control a character with amnesia or a version of memory loss, it is your job to make sure you survive in the vast post-apocalyptic landscape filled with mutants and raiders. The game involves turn-based combat and crafting which both give the game that unique gameplay style that makes it stand out amongst other titles. (May not sound like it, but it really is different)

The game is hard, I really do mean hard. The rogue-like genre means that when you die or lose in game you will need to restart from the beginning, it also means that each map is procedurally generated and so there will never be the same items or NPC's in a single location. With the difficulty aside the game is really fun with a lot of replayability, there is no real storyline yet but it will be soon implemented according to the dev.

At the time of writing this review it is still in the beta stage of development and also in Early Access, from what I have seen and played it is one of the few Early Access games that haven't disappointed me.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNeo Scavenger.Where to begin...A game set in a post apocalyptic wasteland where everything is out to kill you however unlike most apocalyptic games it is set in the pen/paper style of dungeons and dragons.In addition it is by far one of the most realistic survival games out there including dirty water,medical illnesses and poisoned food.If you like hardcore games, apocalyptic games and other along those lines this is the game for you and if it isn't then at least check out the demo!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unlike Pixel Piracy, this game is being develped by competent focused people with a workplan that keeps the early backers fully informed of what to expect. This work ethics are indeed rare amongst Indie studios. The developers sholud be praised by the responsability they take upon assuring the quality of their product, if only that. Good news is the game is, in all the sense of the word great. A post-apocalyptic don't starve with RPG elements, this game left me incredibly happy and fulfilled to the point that, and I almost never say this, think the asking price for the release is not high enough. This Game is worth your money and the developers deserve it. I cannot recomended it enough. If you're a fan of don't starve and/or rogue-likes/lites this is it, you can't go wrong. It might register as 0 hours played, but I played a good solid 10 hours of it while my internet was down.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NEO Scavenger is a rogue-like survival game that was originally made in Flash.
You control a character with amnesia or a version of memory loss, it is your job to make sure you survive in the vast post-apocalyptic landscape filled with mutants and raiders. The game involves turn-based combat and crafting which both give the game that unique gameplay style that makes it stand out amongst other titles. (May not sound like it, but it really is different)

The game is hard, I really do mean hard. The rogue-like genre means that when you die or lose in game you will need to restart from the beginning, it also means that each map is procedurally generated and so there will never be the same items or NPC's in a single location. With the difficulty aside the game is really fun with a lot of replayability, there is no real storyline yet but it will be soon implemented according to the dev.

At the time of writing this review it is still in the beta stage of development and also in Early Access, from what I have seen and played it is one of the few Early Access games that haven't disappointed me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost, do not take my above playtime as my experience, I've bought it on Desura and the Website, and I wanted a third save and to give an additional amount of money to the devs. (Why can't I just give you money?!) Anyhow, this is Neo Scavenger in a nutshell:

Cold. How long has it been since I've been warm. A day? Ten? I don't know any more, time seems so eternal out here, and I've lost track of it. I don't know anything but pain, fear, and cold these days... and hunger. I tried building a campfire a while back, and that damned Bandit left me bleeding and scarred. I went looking for some medical equipment later that night, an an apartment collapsed on me. I'm weak and tired, but I'm too afraid to sleep... But I can afford to close my eyes a bit, right?...
Give up all your f***ing gear if you want to live!" Before I'm even fully aware

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like hardcore RPGs and value gameplay over graphics, you should definitely give this a try. Very fun and extremely addictive. It reminds me quite a bit of the original Fallout games, although it plays quite differently. There are some bugs and balance issues, but for an under-dev game that's apparently being created by one man, it's fairly polished.

NOTE: Try to demo to get a feeling for the gameplay, but note that the demo lacks a lot of features and has a number of bugs that are already fixed in the paid early release version.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNeo scavanger Is a awsome game period, Dont let the screen shots or videos fool you this game is great its crazy in depth and the plot is tried and true, the game is so amazing that I could cut down a tree limb and combine it with a tarp I had found to make a lean to, or take a pot and fire to boil my water to make it safe to drink, These are just a small sample of the variety of things you can create, it almost feels like if you can think it you can do it, Very few games other than project zomboid (also an amazing game) seem to be able to give you this sense of depth, The game is played by reading text and moving your character in a grid overworld kinda like final fantasy tactics, I will admit from screenshots I said this game will suck and its not for me....Boy was I wrong just get the demo play it and Im sure you will buy it, This is the only game I have ever played that I killed a man just for his left boot, This game is hard it wants you to die, but each time you do you learn from it and the next time you will go a little farther this style of gameplay is very rewarding do yourself a favor and pick up neo scavanger, In its current early access state I give it a 9/10 amazing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI haven't reviewed anything on Steam yet, but I had to review NEO Scavenger because this game deserves so much praise. It completely caught me by surprise and is a great example of Early Access done right. I paid the $9.99 awhile ago and I felt it was completely worth it, and after the frequent updates and improvements, it definitely continues to be worth the money. While I do think the UI needs to be cleaned up a little and the story could be fleshed out more, NEO Scavenger is still a great game. From the crafting that is more than just there because a ton of games are including it, to the way it draws you in for one more turn, and then another, and then maybe another hour goes by, I couldn't say enough good things. There are some flaws and it isn't for everyone, but check out the demo and support a developer that does Early Access right. I've so far put nearly 30 hours into NEO Scavenger and I'll definitely be adding to that number as time goes on

reviewText:
A more realistic/hardcore approach of survival game, where finding cloths to keep you from dying in cold weather is kind of a challenge.

Good
1. No infodumping at start, as you explore more locations/nps, you are more into the story.
2. Open world, all you the instruction you get is 'oh there is light there (in a wasteland), let's go there then'. Yet you can choose your own path and not go else where instead.

Neutral
1. No hand holding, again, you don't get any instruction. But you will die a lot at start.

Meh
1. Control, instead of instantly preforming the action as you click, you need to pick options from the left panel to right then confirm. (you can

Tips
1. Rotate items with A and D after selecting (dragging) it
2. If you want more content, download mods in the forum.

reviewText:
This is a little gem. Do not be deceived by the simple (yet functional) art style. There's plenty of atmosphere, rich game mechanics and probably one of the best spawns of the survival genre. What minimal plot is there is sufficiently engaging and the random aspects of the experience, while frustratingly punishing at times, will keep your interest peaked.

Of its shortcomings, permadeath may cause you some gripes, especially with some build combinations and bad luck early in the game. More importantly, because of the lack of saving slots, I have lost my game files due to crashes or power outages. I have also accidently wiped my temporary Flash files (where the save is stored) before I knew better and inadvertently used CCleaner. An auto-save feature (with backups) would've been incredibly useful.

Furthermore, I couldn't help but wish for a greater variety of encounters, since the game's bestiary becomes a little repetitive after you master the steep learning curve.

Despite these nuisances, Neo Scavenger is a very commendable one-man effort.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nReally great game. VERY addictive, so if you don't have much time to play games this may not be for you. Even in early access this game is very polished and I have yet to encounter a single bug. The choices you make during character creation significantly impact the way you play, and the threat of death from a variety of sources is omnipresent. Although the game is fairly complex, it's also pretty easy to get into because everything works as one would expect it to. For instance, I didn't need a guide or anything to figure out how to craft a campfire on my first attempt. That's not to say this game is easy, far from it: you are pretty much guaranteed to die a few times pretty quickly until you get the hang of things, but deaths in this game don't feel cheap or frustrating and I've never had a death that I didn't learn something from. Pretty much everything in this game is solid; the only thing I could say I want is more content because I have so loved what I have experienced that I want more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

That game is now in my favorite games ever played.

It's one of those rare games that you get a feeling of accomplishment when you get some valuable loot and manage to keep it for a long period of time. Even if you die and have to start back from the cryo lab and the beginning is always the same, it's really easy to have a completly different experience while you play. You will never encounter the same enemy during your first travel to one place and you will really need luck to survive some obstacles (for example, someone steal all your stuff while you sleep, including your clothes. The amount luck you'll need to survive that is really really big).

You know that you've progressed in this game when you look back at the main event that happened during your journey. From when you left that cryo lab with only a hospital gown with you and when you just killed 5 dogman with your rifle and your compound bow.

Speaking of combat, this is one of the games where you feel more cruel when you kill someone than in a FPS game, and you dont even see it happen! It's just click and hope to read something that is good for you! Even if you are not reading a book each time you use an attack, you'll feel very cruel when you'll read that he died by lung bleeding, so you basically caused him to drown in his own blood.

Anyway, go buy this game now! Its really worth it!

15/10

Early Access Review

Prepare yourself for a brutal game. This is a detailed, post apocolyptic survival game. I've only got 6 hours in it, but I plan to play, and inevitably die, a lot more. There is a goal to work towards, and combined with various encounters, you'll be busy with more than just surviving.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of Steam's best hidden gems.

The game feels like a cross between Fallout, DayZ, and even a little Project Zomboid sprinkled in. The game is really difficult yet it manages to make the experience fun. And when I say difficult I mean difficult, it's not a question of if you will die, it's more of a question WHEN will you die.

You start in a cryo facility completely nude, save for a hospital gown. This is a problem because un-like other survival games the temperature is a very important part of the game. If you're not wearing multiple layers of shirts as well as pants and shoes you will freeze to death minutes after you start.

The health system is really neat. It requires you to bandage each individual cut you receive. There are also injuries like broken bones that are severely crippling because of how little room you are given to carry things. The inventory system gives you a couple options: Carry it in your hands or if you have a backpack you can put it in there. Aside from that you can put things in your pants. However not even the largest backpack gives you a ton of room so every limb needs to be functioning for you to survive. There is also a range of illness that you can catch. They can be related to the cold, an infection from a cut, drinking/eating tainted water and food (respectively), and a whole host of other diseases that I've yet to experience.

TL;DR The health system is pretty intricate and requires dilligantly repairing yourself if you're going to live as well as being sanitary.

There are bandits and other monsters that prevent you from getting to comfortable. The combat in Neo Scavenger is also pretty realistic. If you fall over or get stunned it could be it for you. Or maybe not. Not everyone in this game is a blackbelt and the majority of people, including you will often stumble in combat or miss their attacks. In-fact even just charging at your enemy is a risky move becuse you could trip and open yourself up to being stomped. Guns in this game are well done and you won't become invincible if you can get one. They are decently common, however, ammo is not. You may be lucky to find maybe 6 rounds that fit into your gun. But guns are not completely uselss, though. A single bullet can end a fight. Being shot in the torso is enough to make you fall over and possibly passout, destined to either be looted and wake up naked and bleeding with your guts strewn about or to get stomped once your opponent has reached you. Bullets will also cripple/break bones so being shot in the leg or arm might not be directly fatal but the resulting infection/unability to carry things could be.

TL;DR Combat is also really realistic and fair (except for when the Bad Muthas are ganging up on you).

Crafting is also, unsurprisingly decently realistic. There isn't tons of stuff you can craft but what you can craft is realistic. For instance if you want to butcher the bandit you just killed, cook him up, and finally eat him there are several ways to do so. Unlike some games where you must have a certain tool this game allows you to use all sorts of simmilar tools to do the same thing. When you're butchering the dead bandit you can use nearly every sharp object in the game to complete this task. Crafting also will occasionally require that you have specific traits that are set up at the beggining of the game. There are a few vehicles that can be made/found and can be used to pull some of the crap you're carrying at a penalty to speed.

TL;DR There isn't much to say. Crafting is realistic but there isn't tons to make.

There is no story right now, so there's not much to say about that.


Bad stuff:

The user-interface is a bit messy.

There isn't much NPC-Player interaction other than killing eachother or NPCs acting indignant when you ask them stuff about the world.

Should you buy this game?

Yes! Even though it isn't completed and there is no story it's a fun game. The devs seem interested in completing this game so it's a safe bet that they won't abandon the project if they make bank on EA. I'm honestly surprised that more people haven't bought this game. Fans of Fallout and survival games will enjoy this game thoroughly. However, if you are not interested in games being realistic and you hate non-3D, mostly text-based, and not FPS games then don't buy this.

Rating: 9/10 Buy it.

TL;DR  It's a good game. If you're still not convinced try the demo.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nReally great game. VERY addictive, so if you don't have much time to play games this may not be for you. Even in early access this game is very polished and I have yet to encounter a single bug. The choices you make during character creation significantly impact the way you play, and the threat of death from a variety of sources is omnipresent. Although the game is fairly complex, it's also pretty easy to get into because everything works as one would expect it to. For instance, I didn't need a guide or anything to figure out how to craft a campfire on my first attempt. That's not to say this game is easy, far from it: you are pretty much guaranteed to die a few times pretty quickly until you get the hang of things, but deaths in this game don't feel cheap or frustrating and I've never had a death that I didn't learn something from. Pretty much everything in this game is solid; the only thing I could say I want is more content because I have so loved what I have experienced that I want more.

reviewText:
This is a little gem. Do not be deceived by the simple (yet functional) art style. There's plenty of atmosphere, rich game mechanics and probably one of the best spawns of the survival genre. What minimal plot is there is sufficiently engaging and the random aspects of the experience, while frustratingly punishing at times, will keep your interest peaked.

Of its shortcomings, permadeath may cause you some gripes, especially with some build combinations and bad luck early in the game. More importantly, because of the lack of saving slots, I have lost my game files due to crashes or power outages. I have also accidently wiped my temporary Flash files (where the save is stored) before I knew better and inadvertently used CCleaner. An auto-save feature (with backups) would've been incredibly useful.

Furthermore, I couldn't help but wish for a greater variety of encounters, since the game's bestiary becomes a little repetitive after you master the steep learning curve.

Despite these nuisances, Neo Scavenger is a very commendable one-man effort.

reviewText:
This game is great!  Paid for itself the first day.  Ultimate replayability, the crafting system is excellent, no lack of challenge and great stories.  I feel like this should be the alpha version of this game as there is soooo much potential here.  Stirke a deal with sid meyer's if you can, but either way this game needs to be much bigger and available everywhere.

Needs more spawn locations, add animated battle sequences (though I wouldn't mess too much with the battle system you've got), more craftables (this suggestion will never change, you can never have too many craftables), online maps, more gangs, recruit a crew and start your own gang and the obvious one, upgradeable and interchangeable skills.

I realize this game has just recently released and not a moment too soon.  Despite my long list of suggested improvements for future patches/releases, this game is a solid WIN!  (though I did manage to sneak past most of the story line and beat the game by wandering to the north, so you might want to address that too).  I highly recommend to everyone who enjoys turn-base, post-apocalyptic and/or crafting survival, styles.
I would buy it as a phone app too.  Keep up the good work guys and gals!  and never forget about us mac gamers.  We know we're a pain to accomodate, but we need the mac for work (most of us) and I lose out on money to sacrifice disk space to run games, but that's our level of dedication.

This is what it would've wanted me to do" I thought to myself silently thanking it for becoming a meal and a coat but also silently hating it at the same time for not bringing any condiments with it.

reviewText: a fantastic and thoroughly challenging adventure game/exploration RPG hybrid unlike any one thing you'll've experienced before. NEO Scavenger's mechanics are constantly intriguing, but more than anything, it shines with the world it presents and the judicious exposition thereof. while it certainly fits in the post-apocalyptic genre, it's a stranger catastrophe that's befallen this world than the usual nuclear or ecological disasters we see; the rules of the universe seem to be in drift. setting is dripped out in tantalizing paragraphs fished up out of scraps of newspapers from before and during whatever disaster it was that set things askew. the frustrations of a challenging narrative roguelike make things that much more intense: unlike a Stone Soup or a Binding of Isaac that can more or less be set aside at any point, NEO Scavenger demands the exploration of its mysteries, keeping the player coming back in the face of annihilation because of the raw power of the strangeness of the world that it depicts.\n\nhighly recommended.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's hard to stop hitting the retry button on this game. While there's no hand-holding in this survivalist/sci-fi RPG, every loss gives you a bit of knowledge about how to survive better on the next playtrough. While most everything about the game is minimalist (lofi-graphics and text/icon turn-based combat), the game's approach to describing characters and events forces you to assess your decisions not based on a sheet of numbers or a cookie-cutter game sprite, but on what you know about your capabilities, and what you can see of the problem(s) you face. It's a great aesthetic that forces you to be your character instead of just playing them. It's a great game, and getting better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's hard to stop hitting the retry button on this game. While there's no hand-holding in this survivalist/sci-fi RPG, every loss gives you a bit of knowledge about how to survive better on the next playtrough. While most everything about the game is minimalist (lofi-graphics and text/icon turn-based combat), the game's approach to describing characters and events forces you to assess your decisions not based on a sheet of numbers or a cookie-cutter game sprite, but on what you know about your capabilities, and what you can see of the problem(s) you face. It's a great aesthetic that forces you to be your character instead of just playing them. It's a great game, and getting better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHoplessly addicted, thats what I am. There are several indie gems out there but I have to admit that this one is the best I've played. Why? Probably because it reminds me so much of the original Wasteland and does well to hold me over till the I get the money for the second. You play as a man with no real memory of who he is and wakes up in a post apocalyptic world, except it doesn't use the cliched desert wasteland or zombie infested urban feista. No, it sets itself apart by creating its own twisted world. In the game you move along a hex map and scavange for supplies. These supplies range from balls of twine and floss to civilian grade weapons and military grade technology. You are able to craft a varity of things out of seemingly usless items. My favorite being the sled (plastic sled + medium length twine, rope, floss, etc.) which allows me to carry more things BUT i am unable to run making combat difficult. Combat takes a bit getting use to but not for very long. It's turn based where you select what you do and you do it then your opponent takes their turn. Simple and when combined with your imagination, downright enjoyable. Even in early acess this game is so well polished I would believe it to be complete, though I'm glade it isn't because I would love to see more and more items and craftable objects. This is a must for fans of classic RPGs, Fallout(original), Wasteland, The Road(both book and movie), and Fallen Paragon(a book I highly recommend find it on Amazon).
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis may not be the prettiest game but it is alot of fun to play even though it's still an early acces game! (Mmm... tasty human flesh) The different perks change the way you play in a pretty big way so it's fun to try out different combinations. Human encounters are pretty nerf wrecking sometimes. A dude with a gun started chasing me for my gear but luckely I could hide in a nearby shack. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like survival games this game is for you!
The game is a post-apocalyptic survival, and it's HARD, but in a good way you never get the feeling that the game is cheating. The combat is turn based and very satisfying, also every fight might be your last, especially if you rush in without thinking, after all it's a survival not an action game. And I love the way injuries work, it's been a while since I've seen this in a game.
The graphic is minimal and almost all the action is told by text so if you don't like reading you will not enjoy it. However I really like the artwork.
All in all if you are a hardcore survival fan I recommend this game, you won't be disapointed. There is a free demo on the official page of the developer, so you can check it out before you decide.

FAIR WARNING: The game is still in beta so expect some bugs. So far the developer is actively working on the game fixing bugs and adding content, so that's good :)

Keep it up!

Please consider creating a mobile (android/ios) version of this game in the future, it seems it would work very well even with only touch.

Overall, very brutal for beginners and has a steep learning curve- but the story and interactions with the mutants and NPCs are very very well written- I was completely hooked on this game after my interaction at Zom Zoms. Love the retro feel by the way. Mad props to this developer.

reviewText: I've always had a thing for wilderness survival games. I also have a thing for not buying early access games, but NEO Scavenger recently came out with their real version. Some people can be bothered by an RPG's strange meta-game of having to micro manage your inventory squares, and this game is not for them. If you're like me, though, and get a strange fascination with figuring out the best way to hold aspirin inside a water bottle inside a box inside a plastic shopping bag (so you can still have one hand free to fend off scavengers who want to steal that bag) then you will find a lot to love here. As survival goes the game doesn't hold your hand and never levels you up, but I haven't seen a system this robust since Realms of Arkania. It's up to you to learn how to interact with the environment, weather, temperature and the like. The crafting system is extensive and partially based on your character creation choices.\n\nThere's no way around it, battle is particularly lackluster: that's the moment you finally realize that you're playing a MUD, with tons of context specific customization but not any graphics to represent it. Unfortunately there's not even much descriptive text to get you into it, either. Still combat is servicable and the options that pop up are fun, and if you're a character where combat is secondary to surviving then it probably won't weigh too heavily on you. I really like this game and it will be fun learning to get better at it.

reviewText:
Day One- Hospital Gown

Day Two- Ate some Mushrooms

Day Three- Hallucinated a Dog Man

Day Four- Wearing His Skin to Intimidate Others

Best case against long term use of Psychedelics


(Some of the bad reviews talk about how saving is an issue and it is so here's a note on saving your game and your rear as this is permadeath baby. It is also probably the hardest game to stay alive even when you are well set up)

Search for where is neo scavenger saved" and find the save folder. This thread tells you where.

https://steamcommunity.com/app/248860/discussions/2/648811852284474523/?l=hungarian

Then grab the save file called nsSGv1.sol and COPY it to another folder or your desktop and then paste it in to the neoscavenger folder and try to continue your game. It might disappear and you have to load it again but always keep a copy in another folder so if it vanishes you still have it) Then when you make progress and want to save grab it and overwrite the copy in your extra folder.)"

reviewText:
It looks so good! It sounded like the survival game I'd been wanting for YEARS! But after scavenging only 2 abandoned towns I was shot at and constantly stunned until I died. I was Tough and had clothes on, not sure if that improves my defense or not, and I was behind cover. Infact getting behind cover was the one single action I was able to pull off.

In my many playthroughs since I have never been able to find another frying pan or torch, and things were even harder. Finding a lighter is so damn hard that I usually starve to death. Or if I just try waiting it out and eating mushrooms in forests, I end up dying of sickness. This isn't a game about surviving, it's a game about taking a while to die. 2 days is my usual record.

This game relies so incredibly heavily on luck that it just isn't fun. But survival is all about strategy, so this works out horribly. I've tried building a great shelter, but died of sickness. Tried never staying in one spot, but got mauled. There are only ways to lose and no ways to win. Also with the very small amount of recipes available, you'd think the game would give you hints on when you need just 1 more item to make something. Dragging the skills into the crafting table is just really monotonous. It should be doing this itself! It's the Minecraft crafting table all over again, with no user-friendliness.

And the skills, they were a selling point for me, but now that I've gotten to play it I only pick the same skills each time. They are just not at all balanced. This is what I'd expect from a game still in beta. I thought I'd be avoiding these huge flaws in a finished game. Incredibly dissapointing. I've tried other survival roguelikes and they were pretty bad too in there own ways.

Starting to wonder if this genre combo simply can never work.

UPDATE: Same day I post this, a wonderful person tells me about a free game in beta called Cataclysm: Dark Days Ahead. It's got more content than I can handle! And despite it's wonky controls, it has a very clear crafting system, and loads of methods for getting materials. It's also far more immersive with you actually exploring the areas yourself. Just hope you don't need graphics, because that's the game's only flaw. To play it like Neo Scavenger, just turn zombies off and NPCs on. And finally, when you die in it, you learn from it. You play better next time. Something I sadly can't say about Neo Scavenger, where it's difficulty is based on a dice roll.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This hex-based, turn-based, post-apocolyptic, survival exploration game is quite unique and fun. The gameplay largely centers around exploring abandoned cities searching for useful items and shelter. One of the best features of the game is the level of detail in everything, every item serves a purpose and every decision has its pros and cons. The combat is extremely brutal in spite of being text based, as the descriptions are very specific and make you think about what exactly you have done; eg 'You kick the enemy breaking their ribs and punctured their lung, they bleed to death.' There are a lot of hazards you can succumb to, such as temperature, sickness, bleeding and starvation.

Overall I reccomend this game to anyone who likes challenging tactical turn based games, particularly permadeath roguelike style ones.

reviewText:
It still amuses me that this game is one of very few good titles available for the Xbox one. But anway, this is Steam version.

One of the mistakes people make when first playing this game is assuming it is unrelentingly hard just because you die a lot; it isn't. It just doesn't have a tutorial, and is very strict. You'll die, but those deaths are not random; they are because of some mistake you made. Learn from it. Don't die that way next time. And don't forget your skills; if you die of poisoning try to figure out why and not do it again. Maybe it had something to do with those mushrooms you ate? or that rancid swamp water you drank? Did you die of Sepsis? Then maybe try keeping your wounds clean instead of rubbing dirt in them.

Once you get into the swing of things, it isn't hard to survive, and luck starts to be a fairly minor factor. This can take a bit of learning; even poring over the wiki isn't going to totally familiarize yourself with the mechanics, but it is a good idea to use the wiki for craftables. Not necessary, but helpful.

One last bit of advice: there's no 100% completion for this game, so keep in mind you do not have to complete every challenge you come across. In fact, you shouldn't try; no character can handle all challenges. Pick your battles, and don't be afraid to run away, even if you are a full combat character.

Most of all, the game is turn based. Take your time, think things through, and use your skills.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing game, even in Early Access! Very immersive and intense gameplay as I have to allot time and attention to different aspects of survival, such as food and water, hiding from groups of humans or mutants, taking advantage of the lone bandit, crafting and scavenging for clothes and gear, spending my nights shivering and wary of looters.

If you like games such as Project Zomboid and FTL: Faster Than Light for the apocalyptic atmosphere, critical decision making, and unforgiving gameplay, then you will definitely love NEO Scavenger.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the most beautifully crafted games, up there with AI War, and it's not even finished yet. The developer is incredibly active, pushing out quality updates often of content and bug fixes. Also pays heavy attention to the community and is well receiving of criticism and ideas alike.

The game itself contains hundreds of recipes, items, and ways to die. The survival system is realistic. You need to eat, drink, stay warm, have vision, scavenge, hunt, trade, and try to keep healthy while doing it. Starving? Those mushrooms look mighty tasty. BAM! They're poisonous. Should have been a botanist, eh?

Oh, you're tired? Cold? Campfire in the woods sounds nice, and man am I so glad I found that sleeping bag. BAM! Robbed in your sleep. Bam! Dogman fight! Oh god, you're bleeding out! Slap rags and a makeshift splint on your torn and broken arm. Ouch, you didn't boil them, now you have an infection.

I've never really been one to enjoy hardcore games. Infact I usually stay away from roguelikes. This one's demo alone kept me in it for two weeks before buying it. Definitely a good pickup for survival and roguelike veterans and newbies alike.

Greg wanted that shotgun, but knew he had to get closer and make sure his bullet counted. The man offered to talk to Greg, but Greg just walked casually twards him. The man, thinking he just wanted to be closer when they talked, started to move closer also. Greg walked right into the man, lifted the gun, and shot him. reviewText:
You wake up to the sound of freezing rain on makeshift tarp shelter. You take a quick look through your gear making sure nothing has been stolen in the night. Shoving the pieces of your shelter into your pack and throwing your hide cloak around your shoulders you take off through the pouring rain.

You rummage through a few houses not finding much, these where the first places to get scavenger after everything went to ****. As you exit the last house on the street tearing an old tee shirt into rags, suddenly hearing a loud clatter you throw yourself to the ground and watch as a large figure resembling Werewolf from old story's lumbers past. It passes by and you release a breath you didn't know you where holding in. Unslinging the rifle from your shoulder you top off the magazine, fighting a dog man today is not something you wish to happen.

A few days later you stand atop a hill scanning the area with half a binocular you keep slung around your neck searching for any movement while munching on a handful of berries. After several hours you see the flash a blue sash moving out of the tree line, a blue frog preacher not friendly and normally carrying somewhat valuable objects you will have no remorse from ending this ones life. Moving closer as to not waste your valuable ammunition you line up a shot from your rifle. With a loud accompanying crack the figure drops to the ground motionless. as you get close the man jumps to his feet and sprints back into the tree line, Swear under your breath you give chase into the dense forest.

He couldnt have gotten far you think to yourself examining the blood trail. The trees seem to press closer on you and your draw a small revolver from your cargo pants pocket, your rifle would be ineffective at these close ranges. The blue sash makes it easy to find the lifeless body after a few minutes. Your so focous on looting the corpse you almost don't hear the rustle of foliage, you grab your pistol from where it lay beside the body and scan the woods searching for the source of the sound. A single shot whipes by your head and you throw yourself behind a log still searching for your attacker. You take a deep breath staying here is suicide, you lung forward from behind the log in a full on sprint. Stumbling over the overgrown roots of the trees you feel relieved as you see the light streaming for the edge of the forest. In all fairness you almost make it before the second shot rings out catching you in the leg. Gritting your teeth against the pain you fire blindly behind you as you break out into the field. You leap into the tall grass silently thanking what ever god stays about for the concealment. The third shot hits you in the back going through your lung, you cough blood flying from your mouth and then the fourth and final shot the only you don't hear finally ends your pain.

Neo Scavenger is a post apocalyptic survival simulator. You must contend with food, water, the cold, the weight of your equipment, wild beasts and other people in your struggle to simply stay alive. Neo scavenger also adds in sides mission and a story although i must admit i have no lived long enough to complete any of them. Also random events can happen while moving about the hexagonal landscape ranging from slave auctions to abandon camps. Combat is turn based and visceral in its descriptions, enough to make you slightly uncomfortable with each killing blow. A skill is also in place allowing you to change your play style with each life keeping the game fresh. There can be quite a lot of reading in parts however its is done very very well, each line adds more to the atmosphere and does a good job of giving a visual of the surrounding area.

This is a brutal unforgiving game Death comes quickly to the unknowing and the unprepared. Its not everyone's game by far taking up a niche role in giving a somewhat realistic survival game, probably the closest ive found to a proper simulator.

I give NeoScavenger an 8.5/10
Menus can be rather clunky at times and starting off as a new player can be rather brutal but once you grown acclimated to the environment it becomes a rather masochistic joy to play. Just be wary of purchasing and watch some footage and play to free demo to see if you think you would enjoy the game.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Basically, this is the kind of difficulty and immersiveness you will find in this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game. It's a lot of fun, and the writing for events is great! This game's mechanics have a steep learning curve, but is just fun after. The combat shows realism, and encourages not beating to death everyone, but rather beating up, trying to make surrender, or even kill with a ranged weapon. Also, the skills are useful. (There is even a haunted house!) Go play this game, it's just 10.00 US dollars, and is worth even more than that. It requires scavenging a lot, and the name live up to it. For those preferring strategic turn-based games, buy this.

reviewText:
The info:

In NEO Scavenger you will be fighting not only the vicious denizens of a post apocalyptic world; but nature itself.
Between the cold, hunger and baddies you will have a hard time surviving.

Finding something as simple as a potato chip bag seems like an accomplishment in this game as you will always be struggling to find ways to carry all the loot you find and and tools you need.
Every item in the game has a health and when that health runs out, it's gone forever and just like in real life if you find a old shopping bag it might have a hole or two in it so there is always the chance that loot you find will already be near useless.
Having to decide whether to go on with a sword that has 1% use left in it verses the completely fine stick just laying there will become a easy choice. But figuring out if the small pocket knife is better to take with you because it takes up less space or if it's worth losing that extra storage to a base ball bat is a much harder to decide.

Every choice in NEO Scavenger could mean regret or death in the next few turns or happiness and success.


Some things to note before buying:
If you like not being able to save your progress then this game is fore you. The only option you have is to 'save' game; which acquaints to going back to the start screen or quitting the game and being able to pick up where you left off however you soon realize it's not really saving anything the first time you die your save is gone. When you die you have to start over again with nothing . . .from the beginning. For me I really get depressed when I worked really hard to get what I got only to die because it was cold or because I drank some bad water.


The good:

Challenging
Tons of content to see
high replay value



The bad:

The random nature of  encounters and item generation is very unforgiving at times and often ends with your character being killed after only a few turns.
A limited (small) set of starting skills to choose from.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGame is a fantasticly brutal survival sim. One character I had managed to take down a military (ATN?) guy with a crowbar, which gave me rad body armor, guns and a pack full of goodies. As I'm crowbarring his unconcious head in, his attack drone comes out of nowhere and messes up my arm and leg. After cowering in a nearby abandoned building that I tarted up with noise traps and tarps, I poured the dead soldiers whiskey all over my wounds and chowed down on my cured squirrel stash. I healed up, bailed the area and with my new armor and arms, became a total wasteland badass for about 50 turns. That is, Until 3 dogmen tracked me down to a forest shack and took turns arranging my intestines. Immense fun, highly reccomended to survival game fans.

reviewText:
InB4 Noob.

There's games, and then there's exercises in sadism.

This is an exercise in sadism.

The concept isn't bad, to be honest; and I don't mind the whole permadeath thing; but the difficulty curve is just above and beyond ridiculous. You can, and -usually will- die just from wandering around, because apparently your character is some sort of lizard who can't stand temperate climates.

This is just one of the many flaws; but the most glaring. This game punishes new players hard. It's very, very difficult to get into. I've yet to survive a single day game time. Unless you're willing to die hundreds of times, just to get to a reasonable point, you're better off not bothering.

Immensely frustrating, seldom rewarding. And even then, you're going to die and lose all your cool stuff, so why even bother?

TL:DR.
If you're the sort of person who likes post apocalyptia; and enjoys inserting thumbtacks into their perineum; this is your game.

If you enjoy post apocalyptia, but are sane, and don't feel like starting the same game ninety times just to get anywhere; look elsewhere for games.

Definitely not recommended.
voteText: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
While I really like the concept and everything:

1) The menus are clunky.  This whole game revolves around those menus, so the game is clunky.

2) Of the 10 tries or so, my character continually froze to death even if I had layered a shirt over a hoodie with pants and boots and slept in sheltered areas.

3) The combat is awkward and does not feel engaging.

4) Finding something to store my items was extremely difficult, so normally I'd only have a shiv or something.

5) Crafting is strange and it's not clear what you can/should build.  You learn more about what you can make the more you play, and sometimes you even find recipes, but finding those items again by the time you need them seems somewhat unlikely.

I feel like this could be spruced up and be far more exciting, but as it currently stands I cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
TL;DR
Neo Scavenger is a brutal 2D survival game set in a supernatural apocalypse where you try survive the wasteland of everything that wants, can, and will kill you should they ever get their claws on you. Also permadeath is on. A shining example of gameplay over graphics.

Game Detail
Name: Neo Scavenger
Genre: Survival, Strategic Inventory Management
Personal score: I never knew masochism and sadism was an art form till today. Fun.

What is Neo Scavenger
Neo Scavenger is a 2D survival game set in a hex based world where a devastation has happened to the world and well, apocalypse thing happen and you are a survivor of it. In first glance the innocent looking graphic and the non threatening looking trailer may throw you off on how brutal this game is but as people often say, 'you don't know hell till you been there' read on. Permadeath is on btw.

1:Gameplay
The main gist of Neo scavenger gameplay is well, scavenging old ruins of buildings and forest  to follow the trail of barebone story. Each hex has a protection value from beeing seen, comfort and how alert you can be when something goes near you. Each of this stats can be improved by items, shelter and other craftable. A low protection from the enviromental will make your character slowly freezes during the night and if their body temperature is already low enough they will die. A low alert level will cause your character to not wake up when threats are nearby and bandits/looter/stuff can kill you in your sleep and you will die. A low comfort will cause your character to fight less efficiently and you might suddenly fall asleep and you will die.

Adding to that, the map is hex form and you have a limited numbers of move during the day and far less during the night to move around, scavenge or perform one of the many in game action before needing to end your turn for the AI to move. On each hex you can scavenge supplies with city tiles having more supplies but comes at the increase risk of being discovered by bandits and obtaining injuries. Scavenging is extremely important in this game because it is your only way of getting randomized loots early game. Pretty much everything you need can be obtain by scavenging. Which might leads to a fight should you encounter bandits while on the move.

Fighting in Neo Scavenger is a game of chances and luck. A fully kited out bandit can still be defeated by you wielding nothing more than a rock but such a thing would of course take extreme luck due to the hidden diceroll system. Based on the perks you have chosen special attacks may not be available to you and only to the perk wielder. A few way fights can be resolve is through killing your opponent, dominating them and causing them to surrender or simply point your gun at them and watch them flee. Even an empty gun works occasionally to fool the AI seeing as in real life you would of course not attack the man with a gun even though its empty but you don't know that.

Should you get wounded in Neo Scavenger you will have to treat them to prevent the blood loss from draining too much and yes it regenerates slowly. Wound treatment has their own special menu where you apply splints, bandages and meds to your character. Left unchecked a large wound has the potential to end your playthrough instantly. Also water and berries you collected are often time poisones because the game isn't hard enough. This might cause disease that has a similar effect to a tired status or in worse case scenario cause a total system failure which leads to your death.

From all the materials you gathered from the scavenging you can use the crafting menu to create items. A wood with a sharp object will yield a spear that you can use to attack. Container with strings and stones will yield a noisemaker to increase the alert level of your campsite. Many other options exist for the player to find themselves.

The player character will also experience hunger and thirst which can be reduce by eating and drinking, failure to do so will lead to death. But as mentioned earlier, most of the water and food you find in the forest where the risks are low are poisonous and consuming them will lead to death.

Inventory management in Neo scavenger are quite realistic in terms of real life, your character has only 2 hands and thus can only hold 1 item in each hands without a bag. With a bag this frees up 1 hand for combat and allows more item to be carried but a bag is not your only means of carrying. Side pockets in pants, shirt and even a sledge can be found and use to help you carry more items which is especially important during end game where you often have to make far away expedition. Any item being held or use will eventually degrade before completely break down into nothing and in fact most of the things found in the wild are actually used goods and so they already have lowered durability. To beat the coldness of the night without a good shelter multiple cloths can be worn on top of each other to increase heat levels during the night and prevent freezing to death.

The day and night system is also quite important. During the day enemies can spot you from further away and the same holds true for you and the during the night the decreased line of sight cause your action points to be less that during the day.

As you traverse the deadly world of Neo Scavenger you might come across strange landmarks or building that will lead you to a random event. Success of survival and loot gain depends on the players perks chosen and dialog choices.

And lastly the perks. During character creation you can choose several perks with perk points limiting the amount. The best perks are usually the most expensive but to help player with that negative perks can also be chosen that frees up point for more positive perks.

2:Sound
Utilizing more ambient noises instead of spoken dialogs the world of neo scavenger is truly brought to life, The forest shakes and the ruined city exhibit an eerie feeling as the player explores it.

But well, good filler is better than no filler.

3:Graphics
Everything is sprite based no exception. The characters are sprites, the menu utilizes sprites and even the backgrounds are sprites but like other sprites these are well done enough to pass the inspection. You can clearly tell what an item is at a glance which should be the most important thing in a survival game like this.

At least they do look pretty.

Conclusion
You will die a lot in this game. That is a fact and i hope i emphasized it enough. But the game definitely do not hold your hand at all from the moment you walk out of the facility till the next moment your guts spilled out from getting stabbed by an alcohol bottle. This game is intense. Fan of survival game should definitely get it.

FInal verdict: Yes.


TIPS!
FIND A SHOE, SERIOUSLY.
FIND SOME CLOTHES TOO WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING FOR THAT SHOE.
YOU WILL DIE. AND IT'S PERMAD DEATH SO GET READY TO RESTART A LOT.
BUT THE MOST IMPORTANT THING IS....
don't eat those red berries.

reviewText:
Wonderful idea, missing in execution.

It's slow to play and doesn't distinguish well in presentation (between turns, between degrees of injury, between how aggressive your opponent is acting) but it still doesn't allow saving.
Don't Starve for example plays fast and you can see how your opponent acts or why you can't run away. NEO is just being optuse and then when you inevitably die you have to go through the same very slow start once over.

Maybe fun to someone else, and I've hesitated to give a negative recommendation since I've come back to it several times - but then the same thing happens over and over again, and I'm back to the freezer.

reviewText: I think this game is super unbalanced in terms of how much luck you need to get through it. It's really hard to survive combat without one of the combat traits but in taking combat traits you loose the survival traits that keep you alive over the long haul. It's not uncommon to spend a couple hours building yourself and your camp up up just to get wrecked by a dog you couldn't out run. Ultimately the scavenging and crafting are alright but the combat system is really what gets me. There is no consistant means of escape and no way to tell how much health your opponent has or has lost during the battle.\nOn a side note I'm really interested in the story elements of the game. I want to see the robot facility and I want to find out whats in the middle of the swamp but I just feel like I'm spending all of my time dealing with malnutrition and water poisoning. This is again another luck based flaw. If you can't find a tin can or a pot to boil water in your as good as dead within the first day or so. In all honesty I think the best way to fix that would be to have more set, consistent points in the game. That way Im not forraging through settlement after settlement just to have varying results of survival gear

reviewText:
Wasted potential. A neat idea made unbearable by an inexcusably horrendous interface, glitches and things that don't make sense and completely break any immersion. More chore than challenge; would not recommend.

- - - - - - The interface is absolutely horrible for no reason other than bad design. You're going to be clicking on things at least five times more than you have any right to. What's worse, once you explore the map a bit, the game begins to be unreasonably slow and unresponsive.
- - - - Game suffers from bugs that have no right to be in the final product. For example, if you get exiled from the city, get a different tracking bracelet and try to get it again, the game will treat the new bracelet as the old one and won't let you back in. What's worse, the only way to get back is to literally wait (!!!) for an entire year of game-time (8760 turns).
- - - - Unimmersive; for a survival game, surviving stops being any challenge whatsoever as soon as you reach the city outskirts and stay there. You can live safely and comfortably indefinitely while earning a shootload of money, and the only reason to leave safety is to push the story forward. Also, the character is supposed to be someone who got dropped into this post-apocalyptic world out of the blue, yet in the extremely limited NPC interactions he somehow already knows about things he hasn't even come close to seeing. The crafting recipes found on random pieces of paper scattered all over the place" thing not only makes no sense

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is one of those low-tech gems that you find yourself immersed in despite it's obvious difficulty and it's lack of flashy presentation. You experience the life of someone in a strange, while still somewhat familiar world and you are left to what you can find to survive among a population that is more aggressive than passive. Friends are in a short supply, as are the means to adequately defend yourself from both the enemies of the world and the elements of it, two threats the game pits against you that are only outweighed by the threat you pose to yourself and your body's basic needs for survival.

Can it look better? Probably. Does it need to look better? Absolutely not. Throw away what you think a game should look like and remember instead what a game should be, because that's what you'll find here. Certainly a selection for the determined as you will suffer inexplicable loss time and time again, but the constant struggle for survival make all of the moments of success you encounter, however many or few that you may find they be, all the more rewarding.

reviewText:
If you ever wanted to play a hobo simulator, this is it.  If you manage not to get RNG'd into the dirt some compelling storytelling awaits you, although you could always avoid it and just try to survive as long as possible.

PROS:
- Excellent atmosphere.
- Smart writing.  It's both verbose and short when it needs to be.
- Mod-friendly.
- Great for both short and long gameplay sessions.
- Visceral combat.  Ripping an arrow out of your arm ans stabbin a man to death with it has a certain appeal.
- Sensible crafting system and multiple skill combinations encourage different playstyles.

CONS:
- It's not winning any graphics awards.  Fortunately this doesn't draw away from the strength of the gameplay, but still...I could see someone not digging the look.
- The RNG God really holds power over this game.  It's hard not to feel like the whole world is against you when you can't find a pair of shoes and your shopping bag full of whiskey and twinkies rips open.  Which leads to my next point.
- The whole world is pretty much out to get you.  There are a couple of somehwat less hostile areas but for the most part everything in this game wants to kill you.  It's like Australia, except Michigan.
- Visceral combat.  It's pretty soul-crushing to finally find a backpack and a decent pair of shoes only to later discover that someone has beat your head in with a sauce pan while you were asleep.

reviewText: This game is the best survival/adventure game you can find on steam up to this day. For some players can be distracted by graphics this game is critically underlooked but make no mistake, this game is hard, unforgiving and overall insteresting. The world of this game holds many secrets. The map can look shallow and empty at first, but if you wander around long enough you can find some really creepy or just cool locations.  Hidden lake for example The combat in this game has almost no limitations, even in most dire situtaion you can come up on top. At least i had one encounter with that happening. There was a guy with a shotgun, i had only a crowbar. I lured him to me without revealing myself, broke both his arms and took the shotty. I felt like a complete badass and you will too. Oh, and for everyone who already owns the game or wants to buy it. Unequip the copper amulet.

reviewText:
Played the demo for a long time and finally decided to buy this game.

Pros:
-Learning curve is very fun and challenging

Cons:
-Very empty characters, only defining traits are those chosen at the start of the game. No real room for roleplaying.
-Story is very difficult to uncover without multiple runs, and when you do uncover it, its also very empty and disappointing.
-Music is so nonexistent that sometimes i forget its there
-Dying is a bit unbalanced, explained more below

If i have a fur coat, with a backpack jammed with goodies, and im wielding a crowbar, i should NOT get killed by a half naked man with his bare fists just because he had the Strong" trait. Also getting OHK'd by a dogman when im in top shape because he just so happened to swing at my upper chest and got a good hit in
date:
causing me to go into cardiac arrest. This may be a roguelike but that doesnt excuse poor game balance by the developers.
Ill play this game from time to time when im bored but im definitely not jumping on this everyday when i wake up in the morning because im so excited to make ANOTHER empty character who i kill with alcohol poisoning because ive survived for about 5 years. (because thats how simple this game is once you master it)

Game review aside
hoursPlayed: its a free OpenGL game
voteText:
and its wickedly addictive.

Rating: 5/10
Verdict: Buy it on sale if you have nothing more important on your wishlist."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those games where you need a good imagination to play. This game offers a whole lot of replayability, Making the map different, and enemy/creature spawns different every time.

This game is very old fashioned Text adventure like, All set on a hex based map, You decide what to do after reading the scenario given in front of you.
One of the core concepts of the game is... Well, To survive, And scavenge. (Hence the title.) I am going to say right now, that it can be a hastle, Having a huge chance to find something and only ending up with broken glass is a real bummer, But you can use pretty much every item has its use, Either in crafting, Or in a way that you'd need to figure out.


Your start off, Selecting your character traits. You start with four basic ones, that are positive/helpful. You can select a few bad traits to get another good one, But honestly right now, The bad traits make things a living hell.
One of the funniest things I've read someone do, Is surrender everything to a bandit, And yes, EVERYTHING, To said bandit. The player had to go and chase the bandit down, naked and beat him up.

The fighting is a bit confusing, and the game could honestly use a tutorial, Showing the player how this works, That works, And even this. One thing im going to say though, is that the games art is great, Ambience can have you feel immersed, and everything. One of my favorite things about the game is finding new items and progressing on, Which has a glorious feeling once it happens, But when that ONE dog-man slashes your chest, Its all over.

This game is actually, very difficult. You can be rocking with great loot, walking around the mall with your coffee and suddenly theres something, you hide, And once you see what it is, Theres no way out. A dog man slashes you, Takes a ♥♥♥♥ on you, and your done. Game over. Time to start again.

I honestly dont know why I wrote this, Probably because im tired and have nothing else to do, But I suggest you get this game and enjoy it. Its for sure, not for everyone, but im going to tell you, if you played Pen and Paper RPG's, Text adventure games, This is perfect for you.
