reviewText:
Wow. This game is absolutely fantastic! I've played many games over the years, and I can safely say that this one is the best I've ever played. It ticks all the boxes for me:

1. It's challenging. A game without challenge is pointless. When you first start playing, you will get yourself killed multiple times, in a variety of different ways. This will keep happening unless you engage your brain, and use the tools available to survive. Permadeath means that you can't afford to make mistakes, which makes the game much more intense, and progression is much more fulfilling. I wouldn't have it any other way. 10/10

2. Gameplay. This game is a sandbox turn-based rogue-likeish RPG. Some may not like this sort of game, but I've played many games of this sort, and it's the best of the lot. Most of these sorts of games over-complicate everything, and gameplay suffers as a result. This is not the case for Neo-Scavanger! The sandbox element is the cherry on top - do whatever the hell you want to do. Perfect! :D 10/10

2. Focus is on gameplay and NOT on graphics etc. Too many games these days look nice, but in reality they have no replayability or depth. Neo-Scavanger is the opposite - the graphics and UI allow you to play the game, they are not there to be pretty . It's graphics and art are still great though, proper old-school stuff. Also, there is the added benefit that ANY computer will be able to run this game. It's built in flash, so if your PC can handle some random online flash game, it can handle Neo-Scavanger no problem. 10/10

3. Depth. This game is deep! I have been playing for a few days now, and I have barely scratched the surface. I've just about got the point where I can reliably survive in the wilds, and have yet to actually explore the world. The game is mysterious, it's hard to know what the game will throw at me as I continue to play, and I love that feeling in a game. 10/10

4.Lore and story. I like anything to do with post-apocalytic settings etc, who doesn't? I havn't really played enough to comment on this aspect of the game, but from what I've played so far the writing and story is top-notch. 10/10

5. Thoughtful developers who listen. Having read a few dev posts, it is obvious that they care about this game. They are very open to suggestions and discussion. 10/10

6. Mods. I haven't researched the mods much, but I know that they do indeed exist. Always great to have that option!

Summary: 11/10. Buy this game now! Even if you normally don't like this sort of game, give it a go! It's cheap ;)

So at this point I would not recommend this. fun play butGREAT way to kill your time to have nothing to show for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I definitly reccomend this game. This game is truly unique and the odds are never in your favor. for example: you could have a pistol and the other guy could have a stick, and you might miss and then he gives you a sever traumatic brain injury. The combat may be just choices, but besides it being turn based, and besides only clicking options repeatedly, its still fun to scavenge and work your way up from having only your bare hands to defend yourself to having a camp, guns, and a good amount of other items. And it gets BETTER! Its so in depth that you could get an infection if you put dirty rags on your cuts, you coult get knocked upside the head and people will grab your weapons and kill you in your sleep, you could trigger booby traps, etc. this game has very good potential, and i dont think there is any way someone could mess this game up for me. some people think its boring? not me. I love it! :D

-Arize_Nation

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's early access and rather buggy and there's no endgame yet.

Yet I've found myself playing for over fifteen hours.

It's a nifty survival simulator. There's a bunch of bugs and design decisions that can make the game utterly trivial, and after a certain point there simply isn't much to do. And even if you aim for the far-away goals, the chances are a bug is going to ruin your save before you reach them.

It's not finished yet. But it is fun to play. If you like dying of cholera due to being careless, anyway.

reviewText: NEO Scavenger is a fantastic, retro throwback to CRPGs of yore and a brutal simulation of post-apocalyptic survival. It's also one of the most frustratingly difficult games I've played. For every bit of smooth, crispy tactics and intriguing story bit you get, there's a death that comes within two minutes of booting the game, or scavenging five different city hexes with every effort coming up empty. It's obviously a very well built game and has a community that loves it, it's just entirely too difficult to have fun with.

reviewText:
Played when I bought it, since then I have been trying to survive, fought loads of bandits and looters, scavenging equipment. In the first hours, my character would die from starvation or dehydration or either get killed because for some reason Dogman(s) love to hunt me down. However on the second day I used the crafting page, and started to read some of the information at the wiki. This went on until I succeeded making the right character with the necessary traits to fortify my base and create alarm systems, and as well as foraging and hunting and making traps, producing clothing and distilling and sterilizing water, and also going beyond to even cure cooked meat with salt(ash).

So far I think this game is realy really what I always wanted from an apocalyptic role-playing game. There is freedom of choice, and also a pretty large map and simulates even in a small platform a deep experience for anyone, who want to feel like role-playing in this large area infested with looters and bandits, predators, and hidden quests.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/248860

I would really recommend you to try this game out, and also help the developers to finish the game and add more content into it. I am really impressed on how much they have managed to squeeze into this game. In my books the developers have scored 10/10 in gameplay and also the healing/medical system and the metabolism and other addictions and features which mimic the human body is outstandingly simulated. Perhaps even one of the first games which has gone so far as to bring in the human metabolism system into a game.

reviewText: A nice game about killing people and eating them. But seriously, this game is brutal. One second you'll find yourself punching up a melonhead, then going to sleep, and dying to a dogman. Extremely unforgiving and luck based. If you find what perk to pick up thought, (Mine are personally Melee/Strength, Trapping, and Ranged), you will survive longer. But the more and more I play this game, the less and less diverse I get. This is due to most of the skills being utter ♥♥♥♥. If you want to actually survive, you got to pick trapping. If you want an early ranged weapon, you got to go ranged. This is a big problem, for the game doesn't really support the other lesser traits very often. Still, a fun game that I became a psychopathic murderer who eats the flesh of humans in.

reviewText: The game is phenomenal, compared to other grid based strategy adventure games, the story is very dynamic but falls short on certain aspects that could make players feel that they can actually become part of this world. There is no option to have a permanent home inside the City, and no option to actually control your faith or figure out more about the past. It would of been a much better choice to have the player kill the person in the apartments or take it over or anything, but I think you have to avoid a lot of things in this game to actually be able to enjoy many aspects of it, because scavenging and surviving just won't do it alone for anyone.

reviewText:
You will freeze to death with one left boot on. This is the game in its entirety. I've played several survivor horror games in the past and I was looking forward to something different. Text/ turn based survival horror appealed to me.  At first, you kinda have to get used to the controls. Click this tab to do this, click this tab to do that. Click this button to turn off the text so you can do the only thing available to do. Speaking of, skills in this game are pretty much worthless.
Ya, some skills actually do stuff. Melee does help in combat, you can Hide while you explore the map, Botany gives you more loot to choose from in forest tiles, some cutscene you use tracking to reveal more text about something that happened when they just could have told you in the first place what happened. Other skills don't matter. Mechanical and Hide give you the ability to scavange buildings safely but reduce the probability of loot while scavenging.  Medic give you the ability to scavenge for medical supplies in the spawn point and gives you better healing but if you don't have any medicine ...who cares!
Your best bet is to hit the road and gather as much as you can to help you survive. The very first town you find will give you a cutscene and a little back story and that's usually it. Most times than not, this town is empty of stuff to take. So, you move out and explore the area around. And as you wander, in the cold and rain, you start suffering from hypothermia. You could" build a fire but in the thirty five- fourty games straight that I played (because you almost always die within the first two in game days) I've found a lighter twice.
Now
date: as you reach near death due to freezing to death
recommended: you get a cutscene about an abondoned car. The car has a sleeping bag inside and if you use the Tracking skill
hoursPlayed: you will find one left boot. You can grab the sleeping bag and carry it to your camp
voteText: which camps always attract dogs
helpfulPercent: and if a dog or a soldier doesn't come into your camp and kill you
votesHelpful: you can sleep for a few hours and warm up . But that just slows the inevitable. For the only out come for this game is..... you'll freeze to death with one left boot."

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game more.

The problem is:

Although the game offers some perspective and interpretation of reality in a different manner than most survival games - like having and observing circumstances" instead of certain stats - I think it lacks the enjoyable gameplay in most survival games. It's sometimes too unreasonable to die and what it offers you is mostly scavenging around which gets quite repetitive after some time. It's hard to understand why anybody would like such a game too dependent on inventory management. Crafting is painful to me. When I try to consider the game content and atmosphere
date: I feel like it lacks certain aspects
recommended: there's nothing really interesting compared to other post-apocalyptic games.\n\nI'm really sorry to say this game is a disappointment to me. I don't recommend it
hoursPlayed: but it might be really enjoyable to you."

NEO Scavenger is a great game that you can play over and over and never get tired of it because its different almost everytime (except for locations i think they stay in the same place I have a really good playthrough atm so im not sure). The traits that you can get at the begining of the game can really help or hurt you depending on what kind of playthrough you want to do. All in all, Neo Scavenger gets a 8.5/10 in my book.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love it, Honestly, i ♥♥♥♥ing love it, one minute you can find a  Rifle with 5 rounds and take down a armed Guard and grab his flak jacket and uniform and run off, and the other minute theres a sniper pinning you as two of the guards of the same faction is walking slowly towards with their pistols, and then you have a long hard fight where you have a little hope of winning, and you die.
That is neo scavenger.
It is the first game that has made me rage like insane, yet love it at the same time as im raging.
You can die several times upon starting during to not finding clothing within the first (ingame hours) hours, and then die from Hypothermia, and then as you hopelessly try again, you go all rambo killing everyone you see without any need to try cause you know you will win, Untill you get unlucky, It has the short term fast paced game like Binding of isaac, but a much more complex system of the game, now that it has modding support i cant wait to see mods popup.
In short terms
10/10
Not a 9.5
not a 9
10/10
It is a unique game, it is one of the golden corns you find in the masses of indie games.

reviewText:
This is one of those games you purely play to just try to do better, but in the end it just irritates you and not very fun.

First off, the game plays in adobe flash player. First steam game I have ever seen do so, and feels sorta cheap, not what I was expecting for the price. The menu controls are a little clunky. For a survival game, I wasnt expecting to get the same linear story line every time I play, and although the map is random every time, and big, it's annoying knowing the correct play-outs of every critical event in the game each time.

My biggest issue in the game though is just how bad combat is balanced, your average battle goes like this; You: Stabbed the guy 14 times with a glass shard. Enemy: Trips you, trips you, trips you, trips you, kicks while down, kicks while down, punch, your dead. Game over, you lose everything.

Cause you know, stun locks are awesome, especially when NPCS get them and you get no counters to them.
voteText: 14 of 31 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ugh.  Let me just sum up my buyer's remorse with two points on why I do not recommend this game:

1.) It plays as badly as it looks -- turns out this isn't one of those indy 'ugly duckling' games that have outdated graphics but excellent content and playability.  The graphics, story and gameplay are all sloppy.  Not to mention the previews are misleading.

2.) The game relies purely on difficulty to make this a survival game, lacking any of the richness I was expecting given the high praise among the Steam community.  One would expect that a game rated so highly would have sacrificed looks for content, and it certainly is lacking in both -- instead it's a series of instant-death by storyline misadventure or because the character is about as hardy and resiliant as wet one-ply toilet paper... despite being 'tough'.

I wanted to have some nice things to say about this game, but I really can't find anything worth the $15.  I would argue this should be considered no more than a $2 curiosity than a game worth the developer's asking price.
voteText: 11 of 25 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
RNG + Grindfest + Enforced micromanage = This. Making a meh-ish game is one thing, but watering it down with RNG poopfest is definitely over the line. Even the infamous Dungeon Crawl tries to make randomness controllable, and this... 'game' is just... too much.

At least in other roguelikes, you get to choose starting options. BALANCED AND MULTIPLE OPTIONS, IN DETAIL. Instead in this 'game', we get take-it-or-leave-it starter's kit with Tetris level freedom of choice. If you can't get to skin the Dogman at the start, you're likely to end up dead like 10 minutes after.

Say that you made the build, got the coat. Well, congratulations, you completed requirement for 30-minute survival. Enjoy so-oh-♥♥♥♥ing-much-DayZ-like loot grindfest. Let's scavenge this! Duh, empty!  And this! Yes, we got completely useless shirts and jeans!

...While managing god-awful award-winning inventory. It's complete nightmare : tiny tiny single slot items, liquids being treated as individual items, all those junk items with no clear given use or whatsoever. Whatever you craft, it it's makeshift, expect them to be broken down like 10 minute later.

If the progression of game itself was fun, I'd bear it. But in this game... it's like kicking the same old ground. Scavenge, find ♥♥♥♥, make ♥♥♥♥, scavenge more, rinse and repeat.

But even with all these ♥♥♥♥♥, I guess people will still play it, because of it being 'Unique'. Well tell you what, go play Unreal World instead. The game is older, with more contents and more things making sense, and less HARDCORE RNG SUHVIVORR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

reviewText: This game isn't challenging like one would expect it to be. Faster Than Light is challenging, Don't Starve is challenging, this game is just plain unfair.\nThis game is completely dependent on luck. The first place the player scavenges from might either give the player clothes, a backpack, medicine, etc, or, and far more likely, will give the player absolutely nothing with a high chance of the building calapsing on top of the player. Going to sleep can either result in actually sleeping for a healthy amount of time and waking up the next morning, or just dying in the player's sleep(players can set up noise traps and all that but that never works). Combat can either result in three hits to the skull with a weapon actually killing the enemy, or getting punched once and dying instantly from it. Though usually before any of these scenarios can occur, the player will just die of hypothermia. People on the forums will tell others that if they get that skill, and this skill, and that other skill, then do this and that, then the player will never die, sure sounds like a lot of fun don't it?

reviewText:
way too hard, way too much luck involved. boring because permadeath makes you start over and over again - which means no chance to follow the story.
it feels like black jack... you try to minimize the chances against you but in the end you know the bank is going to win at some point.
of course you could start to hide a lot and to walk away from every fight and hide your tracks and stuff like that but then the game would become way too slow and it would take aeons to get through the story (and the rage factor after some really unlucky death would rise to infinity). i mean it is already slow because you have to deal with too much micromanagement and some really counter intuitive stuff. now add some permadeath and one really dumb encounter and everything starts again.
i made two posts on their forums about those issues but the die hard fanboys over there don't seem to get the point that everything they love about this game makes it a really crappy experience for the average player who has been lured in by phrases like We serve the core role-playing game market by making role-playing games that focus on:

exploring worlds
customizing characters and equipment
creative problem solving
story".

sorry to bring it to you but in neo scavenger you neither explore worlds (because you die and start all over again due to unlucky circumstances) nor get something from the story (because permadeath + no luck). i played it now for 24 hours and all i've seen is the facility i wake up in and it's near surroundings. creative problem solving: well in a twisted way you have to solve some really creative problems like for example the shoe problem - your player character is too dumb to put his shoes on. no joke. so if you wonder why you wear a pair of the same shoes but still get that improper footwear message just check if the right shoe really is on the right foot and the left shoe really is on the left foot. (<- my favorite example because it really represents just how bad the game design gets at stages). at least you can customize your character and equipment.
it's a shame that you don't see anything of the world and story because what i really like about this game is that it somehow still manages to be immersive.

this game is for people who love micromanagement and boring repetitive stuff. definitely not a game for someone who's into story and exploration and adventure."

reviewText:
VERY clunky interface, to the point that it feels like a bad shareware game from 1991.

Found items in a search? Go click to a different screen to see what they were.

Different Choose-Your-Own-Adventure style options for responding to an encounter? The game tells you what they are, but you choose them indirectly by moving the TOKEN of the SKILL that enables that response, rather than just clicking that option directly.

You can see a MASSIVE list of what you know how to craft, but it isn't context sensitive - you can't click on a branch and see what you can make from it.

reviewText:
This game is the reason why I don't like spending more than $20 on a game.  Put simply, the game is terrible.

At its heart, it's a crafting game.  I like crafting games, but this one suffers from the same pitfall as many other titles in the genre.  There is no effective way to organize one's inventory.  It's a huge mess of items arranged by size.  It's nearly impossible for a player to understand what he has at any given time.

This would be forgiveable if the gameplay was decent, but it's not.  Combat is a complete mess.  I found myself trying to avoid combat because it is simply too much of a hassle.  There is almost no information given about the foes, and who wins is pretty much a crapshoot.

I have nothing good to say about this title.  It is one of the two worst games I've played in the last couple of years.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game. I really did. I'm a fan of roguelikes, but this game tried to be both roguelike and linear at the same time. You start in the same place every time, and while that wouldn't be an issue, it's always the same scenario. That's the issue I have - I don't play a roguelike to do the same tired story missions over and over. It has some pretty unique elements to it, but the things that aren't good really ruin the game for me. In most roguelikes, I accept the sense of permadeath and the inevitability of some unfair losses, but this game takes it to another level, stranding you with little to no resources and then giving you a disease that can only be survived through either extreme luck with the RNG or a very specific item. It'd be different if it was avoidable, but you can contract it simply by getting close to the enemies that carry it - and a nearly unavoidable game-ending feature like that doesn't make for a good roguelike.

reviewText: I have put more hours into the game and come up with some helpful tips to aid the game in appealing to a broader auidience. I know there are j@ck@sses on steam who will say things like btr ply sum x 2 wn" or "git gud" or whatever. I say: screw you. I don't have half my life to dedicate to learning one game when I have a job
hoursPlayed: no acne
voteText: don't weigh four hundred pounds of flab
helpfulPercent:
don't have a mushroom growing from my belly button due to poor hygenie or a sh!t bucket. Kudos if you get the reference.

Anyways;

Tip One:

Permadeath as an option rather than a default. It's a great concept but most gamers aren't hardcore gamers. Your average run of the mill gamer is going to be either a kid or an adult with a small bit of free time to spend with nothing else to do. Hardcore gamers are out there but they're not as numerous as they like to think they are.


Tip Two:

Expand the crafting system. Right now it's only possible to build a tarp shelter as a method of keeping out of the elements. Base building would also be nice. But what about doing things like using that tarp to fix up a building? Perhaps not make it impenetrable but make the building a little more livable. Also; for the love of god... MAKE THE TARP SHELTER SMALLER IN INVENTORY! Sorry but I wasn't aware that a tarp wasn't a foldable object and thus couldn't be any smaller than the largest 'vehicle' in the game.

Tip Three:

Actual vehicles. We see them in Detroit on the map so why not have them elsewhere as ultra-rare loot that needs constant maintenance? A truck for example could provide a large amount of advantages and disadvantages to someone using one. It would make stealth much harder when the player needs to sleep but it would also cut travel times drastically. Besides; what if NPCs had vehicles? Vehicles in better shape to chase down an enemy or to take hits? Either way; vehicles would be an awesome addition.

Tip Four:

I can feel the nerd rage about to assault my comment box already. Put in a difficulty system. Yes; making a video game is an art but still your consumer base isn't going to get any bigger by making the game harder. Some players just want to play for the story. Others are in it for the challenge and even still; some like myself like a mixture of both but not extremes.

Tip Five:

Here we go. Companions. Maybe not companions capable of combat but at least something like a horse or mule to carry about equipment. Humans have done this since very early in our species's lifetime. Why not have our protagonist able to do it? It provides another dynamic such as: what do I put on the mule? Do I put survival gear on the mule and keep my loot close or do I do the opposite? How much ammo should the mule carry? How much water? Food? Wood for a fire?






Good luck. Git gud."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is a bad sign when the demo is more fun than the main game.

NEO Scavenger has, as everyone has said, a TON of potential.  There is just so much they could do here.  Combat feels granular and staisfying, while at the same time being crazy-lethal if you're not careful.  The loot you find feels like you're struggling to survive, and the crafting system is elegant.  Character creation is simple, but offers meaningful choices.  It's got a LOT of good stuff in it.

But the main game also wants to have a story.  And that main quest line feels kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ when it's next to what would make a fantastic open-world survival game.  Since death is frequent, and often from kinda unfair places, having to redo the same quests over and over is unsatisfying, to say the least.  And I'm not a hundred percent sure if the game has magic in it or not, because it sure seems like it sometimes, and that clashes with the flavor of a sci-fi wrecked earth.

Oh, the deaths.  Man.  I have died a dozen times at least from starting a game, and freezing to death before I can find shoes.  I have died because I can't find clean water, or anything to boil water in to sterilize it.  I have died from a single lucky gunshot.  I like how lethal the game can be, but I do not enjoy at all how arbitrary it feels at times.

Also, the demo thing.  The demo shows off a scavenging system where each city tile has multiple things to search.  Do you check the storage shed, which may have nothing but is pretty safe, or do you go for the high rise, where you might get jumped, but could have a lot more left over?  The main game has one thing to search per tile.  Choice : eliminated.  Just right out the window.  I cannot, in good faith, recommend a game where the main game takes AWAY choices.

I very much appreciate what the developer is going for with this game, but there are too many issues for me to reccommend it at this time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got this game in a humble bundle, which is the only way I would suggest getting it. This is essentially a text-based game. The only way you know things are happening is by reading the log. You have buttons presented to you that are options. When you click the button, the log updates. Nothing else happens on the screen. Even if you win a combat, the only indication is from the combat log.

The graphics are awful. The UI layout is haphazard. There are lots of slots and buttons that make no sense. For example, when you are in your inventory, there is a red X in the upper corner, which usually means close window"
date: but in this case it does nothing and has hover text that says "Current cursor mode. (1) Take (2) Drop (3) Use." What? I was able to drag a lake and forest around in my area inventory. Why? The game allows you to hang yourself constantly. It never seems to help or guide you to an appropriate choice. For example

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an incredibly deep game with a ton of customization options but I found that most of the time I was trying to figure out what the developer wanted from me instead of playing against the game itself. A robust tutorial should be an immediate goal. And formatting to fit full screen on standard resolutions instead of playing in a Flash window would also be a great next step. At this time I wouldn't recommend it. But I'll watch it with interest as development continues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely terriffic game. I love the scavenging and survival aspects, because this game does almost all of these right. The dialogue and combat are both fantastic, and the events are wonderful, too.
However, this is all completely ruined by the fact that you will probably always freeze to death. You will not go in the right direction to find clothing. You'll be very lucky to find a lighter. And even if you do all these things, you probably already have hypothermia, and you'll be dead in a few turns. Almost always.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The concept of this game is great, the detail put into the crafting is excellent.  And that's about the limit of its positive qualities.  It's biggest and most glaring flaw is the 'erase your save upon death' feature.  That's right boys and girls, they PURPOSEFULLY designed this game so that if you die once, if, oh say, you cant find better clothing within 8 hours, or you encounter a creature, or you take off the silly little necklace you start with, you will die, and whatever progress you have made is erased.

The idea of a hardcore mode has it place, but in a game that offers such a chance for exploration, that offers such a detailed crafting grid, the FORCED, non optional hardcore mode is a terrible idea.  Want to play the game to explore, see the world they created?  Too bad.  You either blitz the story, or die once to either bad luck or bad enemy design, and poof, congratulations, all your time and effort has been destroyed, and you get to do it all over again.  I suppose this is probably someones idea of fun, but it isn't mine.  I honestly regret making this purchase.  If you're looking for a GOOD survival style game, get Project Zomboid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun for a little while but it gets pritty boring pritty fast.

Understandably you start out with more or less nothing (depending on the skills you picked and if you bothered to use them in the first room) and for the genre and setting thats fine, however when 4 out of 5 Games Ends because you cant find a shirt, pair of pants and a set of boots before you freeze to death in what is clearly not a sub freezing enviroment the initial new game pains are a little frustrating.

On top of that if you dont pickup either Trapping or Botany, you are going to starve to death. Beyond that its rather easy to stay alive. Remarkably easy really.

The trailor vidoes hint at every decision potentially resulting in life or death but ive had very little trouble from noisly ransacking every building or storage unit i come accross with a crowbar and lighter. That might change however if i can ever light a fire... but of course ide need a tiny slip of paper to tell me how to use my lighter to start a fire and by the time i find that ill realise that I dont have the appropraite skill to start fires. Meanwhile Ill have alrleady hacked 2 laptops and a plethora of smaller eletrical devices to gain access to more or less nothing but a GPS that isnt neessisary because my map allready points out exactly where I am.
Basicly I would give this one a pass for now, keep an eye on it though more features are bound to come out in time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is so life like!

Wander around and die of Hypothermia!
Wander around then die of dehydration!
Wander around and die from a cardiac arrest after a random encounter gets a lucky punch to your head!
...
and finally, get to grips with the game, find the plot, do some exploring ... and then die randomly wasting all of your time!
...
Did I mention the fact that you can't save a game and re-load it, therby making the whole mess TEDIOUS!

Don't do it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt no point have I ever had fun 'playing' this game. At no point have I ever been glad I purchased it. At no point will I recommend this game to my friends. I will recommend NEO Scavenger to child molesters, terrorists who spill American blood, and women who call grown men 'hun' because they deserve to suffer. This is not a game for people. NEO Scavenger is a device used to test if a player is human or not, much like the Voight-Kampff Test. Time spent interacting with his horrid program will only expose a player as being a poorly made simulacrum, a hollow mimic, who is not truly alive, because real people play real games. NEO Scavenger isn't a game, it's a punishment.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is the worst form of survival games. It is a random number generator linked to some stats if you don't find the needed items randomly by scavenging your choices do not matter at all and you die. Its a shame because the mystery of who you are has promise and the flavor text is very well written (the world seems interesting) but the fact that all of your choices are pointless negates any intrigue. A game which repeatedly places you in an unwinable scenario until you luck out is more tedium than anything else.
